characters: EXECUTIVES, BERT THOMAS, CATHY LONG, F.B.I. INSPECTOR
THE HIGH-RISE OFFICE BUILDING ON UPPER BROADWAY

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: Behind the opening credits, we watch a montage of RUPERT PUPKIN making his daily rounds as a messenger delivering manila envelopes and packages to various New York offices always courteous and polite in his demeanor, PUPKIN is an attractive-looking young man just past thirty and dressed in a stylish blue suit, broad tie and wide-collared shirt His shoes are neatly polished, his hair carefully groomed As the montage continues, we see that he has finished his deliveries and is walking rapidly towards his destination It turns out to be a television theater north of Times Square whose marquee announces THE JERRY LANGFORD SHOW. It is dusk and the show is about to break. There is a very small crowd already positioned at the stage door -- a few young girls, a few curious passers-by who have stopped to see who will emerge. Three professional autograph hunters are clustered together: MAE, a lady in her sixties, wears a red velvet dress, a lace hat and much too much rouge. SIDNEY is in his mid-twenties, tall, badly-complexioned, slicked hair but otherwise neatly dressed. He carries a brown lunch bag. CELESTE is an enormously fat woman in her mid-thirties. She wears a large cape to conceal her obesity. A middle-aged MAN, dressed in a corduroy suit,    emerges from the backstage door which is guarded by a    large, white-haired POLICEMAN. The non-professionals     in the crowd just peer at the MAN but MAE immediately    steps i front of him with her autograph book raised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the MAN) Are you somebody?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, honey, I'm just a working stiff. The MAN keep walking and MAE returns to her cohorts just as PUPKIN arrives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Rupert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coolly) Hello, Rupert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who did you get?

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: (distractedly) Nobody. PUPKIN carefully places himself near the door, a step or two away from the other professionals.

dialogues.speaker: MAE
dialogues.text: (to SIDNEY) I got Mr. Raf Vallone outside 21.

dialogues.speaker: CELESTE
dialogues.text: (to SIDNEY about PUPKIN) He'd never tell you anyway, Sidney.

dialogues.speaker: MAE
dialogues.text: Then I got him again at the Pierre at four o'clock.

dialogues.speaker: SIDNEY
dialogues.text: Be a dear, Mae. I don't happen to have Mr. Vallone.

dialogues.speaker: MAE
dialogues.text: You know what I want for him.

dialogues.speaker: SIDNEY
dialogues.text: But I have only six Barbra's left. You know how difficult she is to work with.

dialogues.speaker: MAE
dialogues.text: I don't have her even once.

dialogues.speaker: CELESTE
dialogues.text: (to MAE) Maybe Rupert would help you. PUPKIN shoots a hostile glance back at CELESTE.

dialogues.speaker: SIDNEY
dialogues.text: Would you do that, Rupert? You don't feel about Barbra the way I do.

dialogues.speaker: MAE
dialogues.text: I'll give you Mr. Burt Reynolds too.

dialogues.speaker: CELESTE
dialogues.text: (needling RUPERT) Look, Sidney, Rupert doesn't do that sort of thing.

dialogues.speaker: SIDNEY
dialogues.text: How about it, Rupert?   I'll give you whoever you want. SIDNEY starts pulling little white cards out of his paper bag and reading them off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rodney    Dangerfield ... Richard Harris    ... Liza Minelli ... and she's    not so easy to work with either    ... Louise Lasser!

dialogues.speaker: CELESTE
dialogues.text: You're wasting your time. PUPKIN has been trying to remain apart from the other three. Finally he turns to SIDNEY.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: Look, Sidney. I'm just not interested. This isn't my whole life, you know.

dialogues.speaker: CELESTE
dialogues.text: What's that supposed to mean -- that it's my whole life, or Sidney's or Mae's?

dialogues.speaker: MAE
dialogues.text: It is so my whole life.

dialogues.speaker: CELESTE
dialogues.text: Shut up, Mae. What about your mother? Isn't she part of your life?

dialogues.speaker: MAE
dialogues.text: It's her whole life too. The show breaks. The doors swing open and people pour out The crowd around the backstage door swells.

dialogues.speaker: POLICEMAN
dialogues.text: (to the crowd) If you want Jerry's autograph, give me your piece of paper and I'll send it backstage. A number of people in the crowd hand in pieces of paper. PUPKIN is standing next to a young couple, about college age. The YOUNG GIRL has just sent in her paper.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: (to the GIRL) What are you going to do with Jerry's autograph?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG GIRL
dialogues.text: I don't know. Maybe I'll sell it.

dialogues.speaker: BOYFRIEND
dialogues.text: I'll tell you what she's going to do with it. She's going to pin it on her bulletin board and have an orgasm. The YOUNG GIRL laughs unself-consciously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LANGFORD's limousine waits directly in front of the stage door. MAE has engaged the CHAUFFEUR who stands at the door of the car in conversation.

dialogues.speaker: CHAUFFEUR
dialogues.text: (wearily) No, Mae.

dialogues.speaker: MAE
dialogues.text: I don't mean now.

dialogues.speaker: CHAUFFEUR
dialogues.text: No, Mae.

dialogues.speaker: MAE
dialogues.text: I'll get right out. The CHAUFFEUR, smiling, shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A plain-looking GIRL in a black raincoat and black, flopp hat stands on the street side of the limousine, carefully watching MAE and the CHAUFFEUR talk.

dialogues.speaker: MAE
dialogues.text: But I've never been in one. We hear a cry as a celebrity emerges from the backstage door. MAE turns and goes back towards the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The POLICEMAN is handing out the autographs. Suddenly LANGFORD emerges, flanked by three PAGES, husky young men in their early twenties dressed in theater uniforms. There is screaming and some yelling of LANGFORD's name. LANGFORD pays no attention. Smiling nervously, he makes his way towards the limousine. The CHAUFFEUR stands at the rear of the car, holding the door. LANGFORD enters the car and then suddenly springs back. The GIRL in the black raincoat and black hat has hidden herself in the back seat of the limousine. The three PAGES, who have already turned and headed back toward the theater, hear the commotion and swing around. The GIRL, who we shall come to know as MARSHA, hides herself in the far end of the limo, so two of the PAGES go around to the far side of the car and start pulling her out while the third PAGE moves into the limo from the street side. She fights like a wildcat, but the PAGES slowly    manage to drag he out. During the struggle, LANGFORD     stands amid the cr a bit shaken. PUPKIN stands next to     him, staring at h When finally catches LANGFORD's eye,    PUPKIN smiles pleasantly.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: (to LANGFORD who barely listens) How the hell did that girl get in there? Jesus, they certainly don't give you very good protection, do they? LANGFORD says nothing, glancing nervously at PUPKIN.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: Look at you here. Who the hell is watching you? Any one of these freaks could just walk right up to you and do whatever he wants. A couple YOUNG GIRLS are pressing against LANGFORD.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST GIRL
dialogues.text: Oh, Jerry. How can we get to talk to you?

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: Just a minute. This is crazy. PUPKIN straightens up for action.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: (yelling at the crowd) Okay! Stand back! PUPKIN wades through the crowd towards the limousine, pushing SIDNEY and MAE among others out of the way. LANGFORD follows in the path PUPKIN is clearing.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: Didn't you hear me?!?    Come on, people, have a heart. The PAGES have succeeded in pulling the GIRL out of the far door of the limo just as PUPKIN and LANGFORD arrive at the near door. The CHAUFFEUR has been blocked by the crowd from opening the door so PUPKIN opens it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stand back!    (To LANGFORD)   Go ahead, Jerry. LANGFORD slips in quickly. He looks up at PUPKIN who is holding the door, smiling pleasantly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.   Thanks very much. PUPKIN stares at LANGFORD for a moment and then slides into the limo next to him, closing the door behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hate to bother you like this, Jerry, but could I speak to you for a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to but ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you're a busy man. I promise not to take very long, really. But I need your advice. PUPKIN looks down at his hand which has been badly scratched.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have a handkerchief, do you? Jesus, these people will kill you for a cufflink. LANGFORD hands him a monogrammed handkerchief, then check his watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. If you have to be somewhere, I don't mind talking as we drive. You can drop me off anywhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, but I've got a strict rule never to ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I put myself on the line for you, Jerry. Reluctantly, LANGFORD signals with his head to his CHAUFFEUR to start moving. As the car moves through New York traffic, PUPKIN and LANGFORD talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Jerry. I'm grateful for this chance to talk to you ... I hope I'm not boring you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll let you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? Fine. I'm      Rupert Pupkin, Jerry. I know that the name    itself doesn't mean very much to you but    it means an awful lot to me, believe me.     Maybe you've seen me outside your show and wondered who I am. Well, right now, I'm in communications but, by nature, I'm a stand-up comedian. I know what you're thinking -- 'oh no. Not another one.' And I wouldn't take up even one minute of your time if I wasn't absolutely convinced of my talent. I'm really good, Jerry, believe me, I'm dynamite. Now you're probably wondering if I'm so good why haven't you caught my act somewhere, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well ...

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: Well, up to now, I've been biding my time, developing my act slowly and carefully so that when my big break finally comes, I'm ready -- like you were that night Paar got sick and you sat in for him. I was there that night, in the theater. That was the most important night of my life, until tonight, of course. PUPKIN fishes a cigarette case out of his jacket pocket, flips it open and offers one to LANGFORD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No thanks.   I don't smoke. PUPKIN returns the pack to his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: Me neither. I just carry them as a courtesy. How about a cough drop?

dialogues.speaker: LANGFORD
dialogues.text: (smiling indulgently) No thanks. I don't cough.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: I try not to but sometimes, you know ... Am I making any sense?

dialogues.speaker: LANGFORD
dialogues.text: (smiling) Go on.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: Well, that night you did Paar, I walked out of the theater like I was in a dream. All of a sudden, I knew what I wanted. I started catching your guest appearances on Sullivan and taping them and, when you got your own show, it got to be a kind of regular thing. I studied how you built to your one-liners, nice and relaxed like you were chatting, and how you delivered the jokes without leaning too much on them, without saying "here's the punchline, folks." And I watched the way you played off dead audiences, how you let those long silences build until people couldn't stand it and then the way you got them off the hook with that slow smile. You were my college of comedy, Jerry, like a kind of teacher, a friend. I know it sounds crazy, but when you watch someone every night ... But that's all in the past. What I'm trying to say is this. I'm ready now. I've finished the course. And I'm thinking as we sit here talking "Is this it? Is this that one big break?" Is it, Jerry? There is a long pause.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: Jerry?

dialogues.speaker: LANGFORD
dialogues.text: Look ... er ... what was the name?

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: I'm Rupert, Jerry.

dialogues.speaker: LANGFORD
dialogues.text: Look, Rupert. I know what you're saying. But things don't work that way. You can't just walk onto a network show without any experience. You've got to start at the bottom ...

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: But that's where I am!

dialogues.speaker: LANGFORD
dialogues.text: You've got to work your way up, learn your trade in front of live audiences, start playing the little clubs.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: But that can take years, Jerry! Look at me. I'm already 31 years old! People my age are way ahead of me. I've got some catching up to do and I need your help. What do you say, Jerry? All I'm asking you to do is listen to my act. That's all. Is that asking too much?

dialogues.speaker: LANGFORD
dialogues.text: I get calls from agents every day. All they want ...

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: I tried getting an agent.   I did, Jerry. But you know how it is. You can't get an agent unless you're working and you can't get work unless you've got an agent ... or unless you know somebody. And the only person I know is you, Jerry. There is a long pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, why don't you call my office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could I?!? Oh, I knew you'd say that, Jerry. You don't know how many times I've had this conversation in my head. And this is the way it always turns out. That's why I had to sort of invite myself into the car tonight. I know it's kind of presumptuous and I really appreciate the time you've given me. But breaks like this don't just happen. You have to make your own breaks. The limousine starts slowing down as it pulls up before U.N. Plaza. It stops. LANGFORD gets out. PUPKIN follows.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: LANGFORD turn to PUPKIN,    looking to get rid of him as cleanly and gracefully as    possible. LANGFORD extends his hand. PUPKIN goes to     shake it but his hand is wra in the handkerchief. He     extends his left hand. LANGFO shakes it awkwardly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice meeting you, Rupert.   I hope it all works out for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Jerry. I don't know how to repay you. I'm a little short on cash this evening, but, if you don't mind some good, hearty food, I'd be honored to take you to dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, but some people are waiting for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I understand. Well, then, maybe I could repay you with a joke. LANGFORD is starting to walk into the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute. How's this? The      first night you do your show from the coast,    you open this way. "Good evening, ladies    and gentlemen, it's great to be back    here in Southern California where you can wake up in the morning and listen to the birds coughing ... "

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding but unsmiling) Not bad. Maybe. PUPKIN calls after LANGFORD who heads for the entrance to his building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Consider it a gift. Hey, Jerry! How about lunch? My treat!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning back before he enters the building) Call my office. PUPKIN waves with his bandaged hand, notices LANGFORD's handkerchief and unwraps it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the handkerchief) Thanks, Jerry. The CAMERA MOVES IN for a CLOSE-UP of PUPKIN in a kind of

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: PUPKIN and LANGFORD stand at the edge of the foyer, waiti for the Maitre d' to seat them. VINCENT, the owner, spots them and hurries over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Mr. Langford. (To PUPKIN, angrily) How did you get in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's alright, Vincent.   Mr. Pupkin's a friend of mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (puzzled) Oh, I see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's alright. Now if you'd be good enough to find us a nice table. PUPKIN pushes a five dollar bill into VINCENT's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Certainly.   This way, please. VINCENT leads PUPKIN and LANGFORD to the "bullpen," a select spot in a corner of the restaurant.

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: Here you are. Enjoy your lunch, gentlemen.

dialogues.speaker: LANGFORD
dialogues.text: Is Eddie here today, Vincent?

dialogues.speaker: VINCENT
dialogues.text: I'll send him over. A WAITER arrives and hands them the menu.

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: Our specialty today is Rizzofino Dolce Acqua a la Marinara con Spezi. Very good.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: Sounds like a new opera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine.   What comes with it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me. The three laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine.   For two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very good. The WAITER leaves.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: You look tired, Jerry.

dialogues.speaker: LANGFORD
dialogues.text: It shows, does it? It's all these problems with the show. That and the custody suit.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: I was sorry to read about that, Jerry. Charlene never should have gotten the kids. If there's anything I can do.

dialogues.speaker: LANGFORD
dialogues.text: I appreciate it, Rube. Just talking about it a little with you helps. Eddie arrives. He     is a small, slightly-bald man with greying hair and a    goatee. He wears a foulard under an open-necked shirt.     He carries a long sketch pad. He immediately sets up    a small easel and starts sketching

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: Hasn't Eddie already done you?

dialogues.speaker: LANGFORD
dialogues.text: Never mind. You were saying ...

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: Well, I've been giving a lot of thought to your situation, Jerry, ever since I saw you starting to lose ground in the ratings. And I think I know what the problem is. Too many of the same faces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: Sure, people are getting tired of these people who live off game shows and talk shows and can't really do anything. They've seen 'em and heard 'em till they can't stand it anymore.

dialogues.speaker: LANGFORD
dialogues.text: You know, maybe you're right, Rube.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: I'm sure I am. When a show runs out of surprises, it loses its audience. A YOUNG GIRL stands before PUPKIN and LANGFORD.   She han PUPKIN her autograph book.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: What's your name, dear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dolores.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: (writing) To Dolores, who sensed greatness. Rupert Pupkin.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: (reading it) Thanks, Mr. Pupkin. The GIRL leaves.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: You see what I mean? What you need on the show is some unknown quantity, some brilliant talent making his television debut. Imagine the suspense. Who is this young guy? How will he do with the eyes of all America on him? Something like that has got to help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that's where you come in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not? Believe me,     Jerry, I'd give you the credit you deserve    and I'll stick with you. Anytime you need     me, I'll be there, doing a few minutes at    Guild scale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd be grateful, Rube.     I really would.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All finished, Mr. Langford. EDDIE turns the caricature so PUPKIN and LANGFORD can see it. It's a picture of the two of them, facing each other and smiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Jerry, you sneaky ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks good, Eddie. The WAITER arrives with a bottle of champagne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Compliments of Mr. Sardi. EDDIE hangs the picture of LANGFORD and PUPKIN on the wal behind them among the hundreds of other caricatures -- from Bankhead to Sid Caesar to Bette Davis. The CAMERA PANS over these. We hear the champagne pop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How does your afternoon look?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What have you got in mind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, we've still got time to catch the Cubs and the Mets out at Shea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not? But first, a toast. To you, Rube and your success.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Jerry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Jerry. PUPKIN takes LANGFORD's handkerchief and folds it reverentially, tucking it carefully into his breast pocke He claps his hands together a few times for joy and dashes into the street to hail a cab.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: LANGFORD enters his apartment. It is tasteful, modern, spacious and empty. A floodlight shines on a single setting at the end of a long dinner table. He walks over to a large aquarium and sprinkles some food for the fish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the fish) Say hello to Jerry. On a shelf above the aquarium stand three pictures, one o two boys, roughly eight and eleven, flanked by a shot of each boy alone. LANGFORD walks to the end of the table where a covered dish and a New York Post await him. He lifts the covered dish which reveals a large, cold salmon

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the fish) Say hello to Jerry. LANGFORD begins poking at the fish with his fork.    The phone rings. He answers it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Marsha, Jerry. Did you get my note? I left it on the back seat. Did you get it? I dropped it there before they pulled me out. Those guys hurt me, Jerry. (pause) Jerry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (icily) Who gave you this number?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be    angry with me, Jerry. I didn't know what    else to do; I've been trying you every    five minutes, I miss you, baby ...    Jerry? LANGFORD hangs up the phone and then takes it off the rec

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say goodbye to Jerry. He shakes his head wearily, returns to his dinner and tur to the inside pages of the New York Post.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: A cab pulls up in front of an all-night florist shop. PUPKIN dashes out of the cab and into the florist's. The cab waits.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: PUPKIN dashes out of the florist's clutching a single red rose. He hops back into the cab which starts moving.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: The cab pulls up in front of Gil's Steaks and Chops, a restaurant of little distinction that has a few checkered tableclothed tables in the rear and a long bar at the front. PUPKIN stares through the window of the bar at RITA, the bargirl, an attractive, somewhat shopworn blond in her late twenties. PUPKIN enters.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: PUPKIN goes to the near end of the sparsely-populated bar

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss! RITA comes over.    PUPKIN smiles knowingly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beer please, Miss.    Something imported.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heineken's alright?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine. RITA serves him a Heineken's.     She stares at him, sear his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How have you been, Rita? She stares again.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: You're not Rupert Pupkin! PUPKIN smiles broadly.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: How the hell did you find me?

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: Sally Gardner, I met her after a matinee. Aren't you glad to see me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, sure.    How is old Sally?

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: The same, I guess. You know, two kids, a nice husband, living in Clifton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It figures.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: A lot of the kids in our class have moved back.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: I just thought I'd say hello. Here, I brought you a little something.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (recognizing his style) Oh, yeah, Mr. Romance.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: Don't forget to put in an aspirin. It lasts longer. RITA fills a glass of water and puts in the rose.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Nothing's gonna keep it alive in this place.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: How have you been, dear, sweet Rita?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: I don't have an aspirin.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: Maybe a Rolaids would work. PUPKIN pulls out a pack of Rolaids and hands one to RITA who smiles vaguely and drops it into the glass.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Well, what are you up to these days, Rupert?

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: Didn't you know you'd see me again?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: You still going to the movies?

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: You're looking as beautiful as ever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah.   I was a real knockout.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: I thought so.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Well, here I am.     Local cheerleader makes good.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: I voted for you for Most Beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: I didn't have the nerve to tell you then, but I guess it's alright now.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Well, nothing terrible's gonna happen, if that's what you mean. There is an awkward pause.    PUPKIN stares admiringly at RITA.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Well, how are things with you, Rupert?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great!   Everything's starting to break.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Is that right?

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: Yeah. As a matter of fact, that's why I'm here. I've known about this place for a long time. I just didn't want to make my move until I had something to offer you. Everything's a question of timing. RITA stares at PUPKIN as he rattles on.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: What's the matter? RITA shakes her head in disbelief and chuckles.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ, Rupert Pupkin!

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: (smiling) The two of us are often confused.     He's the one with the famous father. PUPKIN waits for a laugh. RITA just keeps shaking her head. PUPKIN looks around.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: (critically) You like this place? RITA shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Why, you got something better?

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: Maybe.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: What are you doing tonight?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Tonight? RITA starts laughing.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: (smiling reluctantly) What's so funny?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (still laughing) You call me up all junior and    senior year. Night after night after night,    right? And every time I'm wondering 'when    is this guy going to stop talking and ask    me out?' Well, now I know the answer.     August twelfth, nineteen seventy-six.     It only took you ten, eleven years to    work up to it.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: If I had asked you out?   Would you have gone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not? RITA starts laughing again.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Because I thought you were a jerk!

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: You see! I was right! But that guy isn't me anymore. I look at my picture in the yearbook and I don't even recognize myself. I'm not the same guy, Rita. A bull-necked MAN in his early forties enters. He waves a brief hello to RITA as he walks by. RITA smiles and the MAN takes a seat at the far end of the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rita!

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (to PUPKIN) Excuse me a minute, honey.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: I'm not honey! I'm Rupert. RITA goes to the far end of the bar and serves the MAN a beer. They chat briefly as PUPKIN watches uneasily. Finally PUPKIN downs his beer and raises his glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss!     Miss! The MAN gets RITA's attention for PUPKIN.   RITA returns to PUPKIN and serves him another beer.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: I'm in the mood to celebrate tonight. Why don't we go to this nice restaurant I know, talk over and times, get to know each other all over again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then?

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: Well, tomorrow night I thought we'd go out again, talk some more, get to know each other even better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much?

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: How much what?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: How much do we have to get to know each other?

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: I don't understand.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (emphatically) How much do we have to get to know each other before we start talking about that job?

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: I'm not talking about any job.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Then what's this big offer you were talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll see.    Right now I'm asking you for a date.    How about it?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Rupert.     But I'm busy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Busy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.   Busy.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: But this is the biggest night of my life.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: I've already got a date. The MAN at the end of the bar raises his glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rita! RITA goes to the far end of the bar. She pours him anothe beer and settles against the bar, resuming her chat with him. PUPKIN looks for a moment and downs his beer. He raises his glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss!   Miss! RITA returns to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that your date?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: None of your business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want to go out with him for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a good friend of mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell him you're busy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's so important about tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything!    You don't understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I don't. It's been really nice seeing you, Rupert. Thanks for dropping in. But I've got some work to do. RITA leaves PUPKIN and returns to the far end of the bar where she once again resumes talking with the MAN. PUPKIN sits for a moment, gets up slowly and heads for the john.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: He enters the john and goes to the farthest of the three urinals. A moment later, the MAN enters. He goes to the nearest of the three urinals. The two men stare at the wall before them but the obvious tension between them renders them both incapable of relieving themselves. PUPKIN glances over at the MAN's face, then immediately turns back to the wall as the MAN turns to look at him. The MAN glances quickly at PUPKIN and then returns to staring at the wall. PUPKIN sneaks a furtive glance at the MAN's penis. The MAN sneaks a furtive glance at PUPKIN's penis.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: PUPKIN emerges from the john, followed a moment later by the MAN. They resume their seats at each end of the bar. A third MAN has come in and is seated midway between PUPK and the MAN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss! RITA walks over reluctantly.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: Listen to me for a second.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: I have work to do, Rupert.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: Just listen. I'm at the start     of something really big. I don't     want to talk about it here but it's    going to happen soon and it's going    to be great -- for both of us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No kidding?

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: So see that guy some other night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rita! RITA turns to go.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: But I haven't finished! RITA returns to the MAN and pours him another beer. PUPKI sits for a few moments, then downs his beer quickly. Agai he raises his glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss!   Miss! The MAN leans over the bar and tells RITA something. She opens a bottle of beer and hands it to the MAN who slides it down the bar towards PUPKIN. As the beer reaches the middle of the bar, the THIRD MAN seated midway between PUPKIN and the MAN raises his beer glass to take a sip ju as the sliding beer bottle passes under his hand. The bottle stops right in front of PUPKIN who takes it and slides it back with equal force. At this moment, the THIR MAN in the middle has finished his sip and has just place the THIRD MAN's glass on the counter. The beer bottle collides with the THIRD MAN's glass, creating a mess. RIT glares at PUPKIN as does the THIRD MAN. PUPKIN shrugs an apology and RITA cleans up the mess.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (to the THIRD MAN) I'll get you another one. As RITA cleans up the mess and pours a fresh beer, the MA walks down the bar towards PUPKIN. He leans over him and puts a supposedly friendly paw on his shoulder. PUPKIN glances distastefully at the MAN's hand on him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to PUPKIN) Look,    friend. I'm trying to have a nice    civilized conversation with the young    lady. Be a good little lad, huh,    and give us a break. PUPKIN looks up at the MAN who pats him on the back in a gesture of fraudulent friendship and menace. PUPKIN burps With an effort, the MAN controls his temper and returns t his seat at the end of the bar. PUPKIN instantly raises his glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss!     Miss! The MAN advances towards PUPKIN with another bottle of beer. PUPKIN watches passively as the MAN pours half the bottle into PUPKIN's breast pocket and slams the half-emp bottle on the counter. The MAN walks down to the end of the counter where a smiling RITA is waiting. PUPKIN again gulps his beer down. RITA and the MAN stare at PUPKIN expecting him to raise his glass and call for another beer. PUPKIN just sits there. After a few moments, RITA and the MAN resume their conversation, but they keep glancing over at PUPKIN, expecting him to interrupt them with a call for beer at any moment. PUPKIN continues to sit there. Just as RITA and the MAN have settled back into their conversation, PUPKIN falls like a stone from the barstool onto the floor. He lies motionless. RITA and the MAN look at PUPKIN for a moment while the handful of other patrons glance at him and retu to their drinks. RITA leaves the bar and goes to the rear of the restaurant, disappearing into the kitchen. As she does, the MAN walks over to where PUPKIN is lying inert and prods him cruelly with his foot.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: C'mon, schmuck, wake up so I can kick your ass outta here. The MAN turns to the kitchen to see if RITA is returning. As he does, PUPKIN carefully opens one eye, grabs a free chair from a nearby cocktail table, rises and bangs the M smartly over the head. The MAN falls, out cold. PUPKIN straightens up quickly as the other patrons look on with interest. PUPKIN brushes off his suit, which is blue, jus like the MAN's, and stands above the MAN just as the MAN stood above him, his back to kitchen. RITA emerges from the kitchen with the owner, MR. NICHOLS and a large black COOK.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (to NICHOLS) He was making trouble one minute and the next he was on the floor. RITA automatically reaches out as she talks for what she thinks is the MAN's arm. Instead, PUPKIN turns around smiling, leaving her too startled to speak. NICHOLS and the COOK lift the MAN to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, buddy, here we go. NICHOLS and the COOK lead the MAN, who is still groggy, o of the bar as RITA continues to stare at PUPKIN with a mixture of curiosity and amusement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Tarzan. Where do we eat tonight?

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: We are in the kitchen watching two dishes being chopped, shredded and boiled in deep fat. The activity is frantic. WE FOLLOW the two dishes as a WAITER carries them from th kitchen to a booth where PUPKIN and RITA are talking. It is a painfully plain restaurant, shaped in a rectangle, with booths lining either side and a row of little tables in between. At the back is the kitchen and two phone booths, facing each other. An old Chinese WOMAN mans the cash register by the door. The WAITER sets the dishes dow before RITA and PUPKIN and clears an enormous plate of spare rib bones from RITA's place. RITA hands the WAITER her empty cocktail glass. RITA and PUPKIN are facing one another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another one, Chan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to WAITER)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chopsticks, please. The WAITER nods and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So all this time you've been thinking about me, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right, Rita.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kinds of things were you thinking? PUPKIN drops his eyes shyly.      RITA starts laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, ho! Those kinds of things!    Shame on you, Rupert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rita, I assure you there was ...

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Rupert Pupkin is an unclean person!

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: Come on, Rita. People will hear.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (in a whisper) Rupert Pupkin is an unclean person. Oh, come on, Rupert. Relax. Have a little fun. WAITER arrives with RITA's drink and chopsticks and a bee for PUPKIN.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: This is a very important evening to me, Rita.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Did you know your nose wiggled when you talked? PUPKIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It does?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Yeah. Just the tip. Like a rabbit. (pause) Hey, are we gonna eat or what? I'm starving. PUPKIN serves RITA.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: It always looks like they put worms in this stuff. PUPKIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just taste. RITA tastes.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Well, I guess it won't kill me.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: This is supposed to be the finest Cantonese cuisine in the city.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Yeah? Then what happened to the tablecloths? PUPKIN drops his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Oh, don't worry about it.   This is fine. (She takes a long drink) I'm having a good time. So you've been devoted to me, huh?

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: I used to see you at the Garden every year.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Oh, the Follies. That was the right name for 'em. How did you know which one was me? We all looked like chickens. What I mean is, we all looked like the same chicken. I thought it was gonna be Rita Keane in the Ice Follies and I wind up looking like Henny Penny. RITA chuckles to herself.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: You just didn't get the breaks.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Breaks, bullshit! My parents didn't have the money for the right coach. But what difference does it make? She starts laughing to herself.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: I remember once we were down in Atlanta and the ice machine broke down. We did three hours of slush. Everyone was falling on their faces and hopping up with their arms open for a bow like the whole thing was planned. And the people ate it up.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: I liked the show.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Yeah? The Follies? You really must have been carrying the torch. What did you think when I got married? You knew I got married?

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: I knew it wouldn't last.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: You think I should have married you, instead, huh?

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: Peter Drysdale!     Really, Rita!

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: If he'd only been hit by a train. He was worth a helluva lot more dead than alive, I can tell you that. RITA raises her glass to the WAITER who is standing nearb talking with another WAITER. As she does, a nice-looking young MAN sitting in the middle aisle raises his glass of beer to her and drinks it, as a kind of toast. RITA smiles briefly and her eyes return to PUPKIN. The YOUNG MAN is seated behind PUPKIN, facing RITA. The WAITER come over and collects the glass. Throughout the rest of the scene, a subtle flirtation continues between RITA and the YOUNG MAN.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: Are you seeing anyone? RITA starts for a moment, thinking PUPKIN has caught her looking at the YOUNG MAN.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: I want to know about the competition, that's all.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Well, tomorrow night, I've got a date with Joe Namath -- you know Joe. And Thursday --- let's see --

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: I'm serious, Rita.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (imitating him) I'm serious, Rita. (In her own voice) Sure I see people. I'm not a nun, Rupert. I see a lot of people.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: Anyone special?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (chuckling) You mean am I "going steady"?   Rupert, I'm thirty-one years old!

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: What about that guy tonight?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Him?

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: Why him?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: What am I supposed to do, huh? Sit home watching TV? He's just some guy. He's got his own aluminum siding business. He comes into the city sometimes, that's all.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: You don't go out with him for his money?!?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Oh, horrors! Look, Rupert, what do you think they pay me in that dump? Ninety-five bucks. And you don't get the world's greatest tippers in there either. Somebody has to take care of me.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: That's what I want to talk to you about, Rita. The WAITER arrives with RITA's drink.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: Who's your favorite movie star?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: You are, Rupert.     Especially your nose.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: Just tell me.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Is this some kind of game? Are you going to tell me something about my character? PUPKIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll see.    Give me his name.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: I can't think of anybody.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: You've got to have one, Rita. Everybody does.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Okay. Okay. Let's see.       (pause) Marilyn Monroe. PUPKIN slowly pulls out a leather-bound book from his inside jacket pocket. RITA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Rupert!    Are we going to exchange phone numbers!? PUPKIN expertly flips to a middle page in the book and, keeping the book open, his finger pointing under a name, he turns the book to RITA.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: That's her name.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: Her name! She signed this herself, especially for me. RITA starts flipping through the book, curious about the other names. She isn't paying any attention to what PUPKI is saying.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: She wasn't a great actress but she had a real gift for comedy. She died tragically, you know, alone, like so many of the world's most beautiful women. I'm going to see that doesn't happen to you, Rita.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Who's this one? PUPKIN checks the book.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: Burt Reynolds.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Oh yeah, the guy with no clothes. Who's this? PUPKIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mel Brooks. RITA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And this?

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: Carol Burnett. RITA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No kidding.    How about this?

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: Glenda Jackson.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Never heard of her.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: (pointing to other names) And that's Woody Allen and there's Ernie Kovacs -- he's dead -- and that one's Lauren Bacall.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: You don't really know any of these people?

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: Take a look at this. PUPKIN flips to one of the back pages and shows a name to RITA.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (squinting) I can't make it out. PUPKIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Try.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: This is really weird handwriting! Exasperated, PUPKIN follows the name in question with his index finger.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: Rooooper ....

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (guessing) Redford!

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: That's Robert Redford. RITA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is? PUPKIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!    It's ... it's Rupert Pupkin PUPKIN tears out the page and hands it to her shyly.   RI just stares at it and back at PUPKIN.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: Don't lose it. It's going to be worth something in a couple of weeks. RITA start laughing.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: That's what I've been trying to tell you. Things are really breaking for me. I'm ticketed for stardom. RITA laughs harder, despite efforts to be serious.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: Only a couple of hours ago, I was talking to Jerry Langford, the Jerry Langford. Stop it, Rita! RITA pulls herself together for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: We were talking about my doing my act on his show.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (suppressing a smile) Your act? PUPKIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get    that guy you knew from Clifton out of    your head right now. You're looking at    Rupert Pupkin, Rita. Rupert Pupkin, the    new King of Comedy. RITA starts laughing hysterically, in spite of herself.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (getting a grip on herself) I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: Why not me, Rita? A guy can always get what he wants if he's willing to pay the price. All it takes is a little talent and sacrifice and the right break. If you've got a friend in the right place, that's all it takes. And that's exactly what I have going for me right now. After all, crazier things have happened. RITA listens silently for a moment, then begins to giggle As PUPKIN resumes speaking, we CUT between RITA and the YOUNG MAN. Their flirtation picks up steam. The YOUNG MAN raises his eyebrows as if to ask, "Are you interested in me?" She smiles. All the while, PUPKIN rattles on.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: You just don't realize what a shot on the Langford Show can mean. That's coast to coast, national TV, a bigger audience than the greatest comedians used to play to in a lifetime. A shot like that means a free ticket on the comedy circuit -- Flip Wilson one week, Cosby the next, then Sonny and Cher or Carol Burnett. And you've always got those other talk shows to fall back on -- Carson, Griffin. And all that leads straight in one direction, Rita -- Hollywood! That's when we really start living. How does this sound to you -- a beach house in Malibu, right on the ocean. You'll get a beautiful tan, believe me. And we'd keep a suite at the Sherry. That's the only place to stay when you're big. We could get something on a top floor and look down on all our old friends in Clifton and just laugh. How does that sound to you?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: It sounds wonderful, Rupert, and I really hope you get what you want. But it's getting late and I'm a working girl. You know what I mean? The telephone at the back of the restaurant starts ringin A WAITER in the background moves slowly to answer it.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: You going to spend the rest of your life in that place? Is that what you really want, talking about nothing with nothings? I thought you wanted something a little better than that and that's what I'm offering. Every King needs a Queen, Rita. I want you to be mine. What do you say?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: You really want to help me out? You see this. (She points to her lower back molar) A hundred seventy-five bucks. If you could spare fifty, say, until next Monday, that would keep three people really happy -- me, my landlord and my dentist. During RITA's speech, the WAITER has been working his way from the phone booth towards the front of the restaurant.

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: Telephone for you, Miss.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (looking puzzled) Me? Nobody knows I'm here.   You didn't tell anybody, did you?

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (getting up) What the hell's going on? CAMERA FOLLOWS RITA, who walks to the back of the restaurant and picks up the dangling receiver in one of the two facing booths, the other of which is occupied.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who do you think it is? I've been staring at you all evening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you? The YOUNG MAN taps forcefully with his index finger on th glass door of his booth. RITA, hearing the noise, turns around and finds herself staring at the YOUNG MAN. She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: PUPKIN at the table looking over the check. He gets out a ten dollar bill. RITA emerges from the booth in nervous high spirits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with repressed gaiety)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know who that was -- the bar.       I have to go back to work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did they know you were here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gathering her things)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess I must have told them.      They need someone right away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (accusingly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't even care, do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no.   I do. Really!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not the bar, Rita.    Don't tell me it's the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be angry. It has nothing to do with you. I had a nice dinner, really. It was great seeing you again. PUPKIN stare at her icily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on.    Let's see a smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't we finish the evening up at the bar together? End the evening where it began?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After what happened there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I could at least drop you off!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hurriedly making up her face)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's okay. Really. I can manage. Why don't you just go to a movie or something? Don't let me spoil your evening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But that wouldn't be right. RITA gets up and stands before PUPKIN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (firmly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Rupert. It's been a lot of fun, really. I'll see you sometime, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Rita! RITA starts moving towards the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Rupert.      I'm in a hurry. RITA marches out with PUPKIN trailing behind. He throws the check and the ten dollar bill at the CASHIER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA FOLLOWS PUPKIN as he streaks out the door and jump into the adjacent doorway, immediately peering down the street. He spies the YOUNG MAN and RITA walking about three quarters of a block down and follows them, keeping out of sight. They turn occasionally to see if he's around, then stop turning. They go around the corner and disappear into a large apartment building. PUPKIN rushes after them,   positioning himself across from    the buil He searches   the windows for some clue as to    where th have gone.    Finally a set of lights go on on    the fou floor and a   MAN's shadow is seen closing two    sets of blinds.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: PUPKIN enters the building and finds himself in a small entranceway. The door to the lobby is locked. Next to the door, on the wall, are listed the tenants, their apartment numbers and a button next to each name. There i an intercom speaker. There are eight apartments listed on the fourth floor, running from 4A to 4H. PUPKIN looks the over, takes a deep breath and pushes 4A.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: It is an extremely well-furnished studio apartment with a the requirements of a contemporary bachelor pad -- an imitation bearskin rug, nice bookshelves including an elaborate stereo system, recessed lighting, including a soft spotlight on the Queen-sized bed with its pseudo-sat cover. The YOUNG MAN and RITA stand in the middle of the room. RITA looks about uneasily. No intercom buzzer sound

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welcome to the pleasure dome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't kid around, do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do alright. What's your libation?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your potion. Your drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bourbon and soda.   Make it light. The YOUNG MAN goes to his chic little bar and starts fixi RITA a strong bourbon and soda. He also fixes himself a strong scotch and water. As he works, they talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You from the South?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what Southern people drink. Lots of bourbon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do people from Jersey drink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I make it a point to study things like that. It's important to know people's backgrounds, their tastes, their culture. It gives you a little head start. The YOUNG MAN turns from the bar and hands RITA her drink

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Chet. Whom do I have the pleasure of serving?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pleased to meat you, Mary. (He lifts his glass) To our evening.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: PUPKIN stands before the intercom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rita Keane.    I want to talk to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rita Keane?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right. Oh, never mind.      I must have the wrong apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no Rita here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.     I know. I'm sorry to bother you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must have the wrong apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. PUPKIN pushes 4B.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: RITA is seated on the couch. The YOUNG MAN is putting a record on the phonograph. Once again, the intercom doesn' sound. PUPKIN has drawn another blank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leisure is America's fastest growing industry. Did you know that? Think about it. Short work weeks, more vacation. People need something to do with all that time and that's where I come in. Leisure Villages, Inc. We buy land an hour or so outside your metropolitan centers. We set up the bungalows, dig some lakes, lay out a golf course, you know, fix the whole place up so it's usable. Then young, personable guys like me show the people around. It the guy seems tight, we point out the investment factor. If he's a swinger, well, the bungalows are very private. If he's a sports nut, we talk up skiing and fishing and tennis. The phonograph starts playing Burt Bachrach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your work, Mary? The YOUNG MAN walks back to her and stands over her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me.   I fly for National.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (delighted)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No kidding?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that smell?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sandalwood incense. It seemed very you.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: PUPKIN yells into the intercom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said I'm sorry! We hear the intercom at the other end click off.   PUPKIN pauses a moment and pushes 4C.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: RITA and the YOUNG MAN are seated on the couch. Still no buzzer. As the YOUNG MAN talks, RITA is staring at a woman's shoe lying underneath a small table that holds a lamp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you know that you have remarkable hair?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah? You know what?       I feel like going to a movie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. Why not? It's only twenty of ten. We can make a ten o'clock show. The YOUNG MAN takes her hands and looks deep into her eye

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't we make our own movie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.    I don't think so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be so uptight. Give it a chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to go to the movies, that's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can go to the movies later. RITA pulls her hands away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's stop playing games, okay. I'm not a kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have something against pleasure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just not interested in being tonight's ritual sacrifice, okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shall I freshen up your drink? RITA shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (growing irritated)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What exactly did you think we were going to do up here?

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: PUPKIN pushes 4D and waits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: The YOUNG MAN is practically sitting on RITA's lap.   He has RITA backed up against the end of the couch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, if you've got sexual problems let's talk about them. It helps clear the air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's nothing wrong with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then it's me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't even know you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then find out. Sex is a great way of breaking down barriers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure this could lead to something beautiful. The YOUNG MAN kisses RITA roughly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Passive resistance, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's just write this thing off as a big mistake. What do you say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong with me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing.   I just want to go home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can see I'm not turning you on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You noticed that, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on.   What's wrong with me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You really want to know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can I put it? Well, it's like you've got your fly open and your tongue hanging out.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: PUPKIN, growing more frantic, pushes 4E.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: The YOUNG MAN is all over RITA.      No buzzer sounds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm really a very sensitive person.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on.   Get offa me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes I write poetry. RITA pulls herself away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you wanna play hard to get, huh? The YOUNG MAN grabs her.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: PUPKIN, even more desperate, pushes 4F.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Que es, por favor?

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: The YOUNG MAN is strong-arming RITA who is beginning to get frightened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on.   Let's talk this over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I admire you very much.    I respect you, Mary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (her eyes beginning to fill with terror)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're hurting me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm only doing what you want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pleading, on the verge of tears)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, please.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: PUPKIN, frantic, pushes 4G.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: The YOUNG MAN has RITA securely pinned and is starting to undo her blouse. She is desperate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Afterwards, you'll thank me. The buzzer sounds with great force.        It is one, lon protracted blast that breaks the YOUNG MAN's concentratio RITA takes advantage of the distraction to grab her bag and rush out as the buzzer continues to sound.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: PUPKIN still has his finger on 4G as RITA rushes out the EXIT door next to the elevator and comes rushing towards him. She is numb and emotionally exhausted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rita!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in desperation)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want? RITA keeps walking out of the entranceway and onto the street. PUPKIN is at her side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be angry with me.     I was worried about you, that's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just go home and leave me alone. PUPKIN take off his jacket and puts if around RITA's shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here. You'll need this.      It's getting chilly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so bad.   I'm such a dummy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't say that, Rita.     Everyone does crazy things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not all the time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll get us a cab. PUPKIN rushes into the street and hails a cab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 32   EXT: WEST 56th STREET BETWEEN EIGHTH AND NINTH AVENU

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: WE SEE the taxi pull up in front of one of those middle- class tenements -- a fairly well-preserved six-story building with a fire escape running up the front. PUPKIN helps RITA out of the taxi. A dime bounces at PUPKIN's feet.

dialogues.speaker: CAB DRIVER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Stuff it, big spender! PUPKIN pays no attention.   He walks RITA to her front stoop.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Well, I guess you're entitled to come up for coffee.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: That's okay, Rita. You're tired and I know I'm not always the easiest guy to be with. There is a pause.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (puzzled) What do you want, Rupert?

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: (softly) You don't understand anything, do you? I love you, Rita. I want to change your life ... if you'll only give me a chance. RITA just shakes her head sadly.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: Look, what if I arranged it so you could meet Jerry? You'd have to believe me if you heard it from him.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: There's no ...

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: I'll arrange that, Rita. We'll all go out to dinner some night or maybe out to his place, on a weekend. You'll see. The trouble with you is you've got no faith. Now go to bed and get a good rest and I'll see you in a couple of days. PUPKIN gives RITA a very gentle, sweet kiss on the forehead.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: (gently) Now run along in. RITA just stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on. RITA turns slowly and goes in.       She looks back.   PU gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 33   EXT:   MADISON AVENUE AND 48th STREET - DAY PUPKIN carries a large manila folder into 424 Madison. usual, he is impeccably dressed.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: It is a large corner office, broken up by glass dividers. A RECEPTIONIST sits at a desk facing the door. PUPKIN ent

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. PUPKIN hands the RECEPTIONIST the package.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need somebody to sign. You can sign anything you want -- Cary Grant, Art Carney, I don't care. The RECEPTIONIST signs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you mind very much if I used your phone? It's local.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be, long. Dial nine. PUPKIN takes out a little piece of paper from his suit pocket and dials a number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tense, nervous)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I speak to Jerry Langford, please? Thanks ... Jerry Langford, please. Rupert Pupkin ... Jerry knows. I'm calling at his request ... I see. That's alright. I'll call him again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not Jerry Langford, the ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling proudly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.   Thanks for your phone.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: PUPKIN approaches Times Square phone booth. He rests a few folders on a trash basket just outside the booth. He enters the booth and dials.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry Langford, please ... May I speak to Jerry Langford, please ... Rupert Pupkin, I called earlier ... I see. How long do you expect that'll last? Oh, fine. I'm at (PUPKIN checks the number on the phone) CH 4-1482 ... I'll be here for another half hour, forty- five minutes. Please be sure he gets my message. Thanks. PUPKIN hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: A SHOT of the clock on the Allied Chemical Building. It reads 10:10. A nearby record store starts blasting music into the street through a loudspeaker. The music serves as background for a montage in which we CUT BETWEEN the clock, which moves in bites towards 11:30 to Broadway as it looks to PUPKIN in the booth -- that cavalcade of hustlers, whores, housewives, kids, weirdos and working people; and SHOTS of various people waiting to use the phone -- their impatience, anger, disgust. Each time one of them arrives, PUPKIN pretends to thumb through the pho book and dial a number. WE WATCH him chatting with animation until the waiting party leaves. Then WE SEE him push the coin return to retrieve his dime. Finally, PUPKI takes a last look at the clock.   WE SEE that it reads 11:30. He leaves the booth and goes to the trash basket. His packages have been swiped.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: WE SEE PUPKIN enter. He is watched by a plain girl of about twenty in a black raincoat and a floppy black hat whom we recognize as MARSHA.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: PUPKIN emerges from the elevator and walks down the corridor looking for the door the Jerry Langford Show offices.   He finally finds it and enters.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICES
dialogues.text: A bored, plump, middle-aged RECEPTIONIST sits behind a large desk that holds a phone receiver connected to a small switchboard. PUPKIN presents himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Langford, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pupkin.    Rupert Pupkin. The RECEPTIONIST puts a call through. Wide-eyed, PUPKIN observes the blow-ups of Langford talking with various celebrities.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: LANGFORD is seated at his desk on stage and PUPKIN is his guest. WE SEE television cameras and in the background, the control room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know the secret of dieting, Jerry? Grapefruit. It's good for you. It's filling. And it's low in calories.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the camera)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take note of that, you ladies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a matter of fact, yesterday I went to the outdoor market near where I live and I bought twenty grapefruit. The grocer looked at me and said, "What are you gonna do with all those?" So I bent over and told him (in a confidential tone) "I'm gonna take 'em back to Florida and set 'em free!" LANGFORD and the AUDIENCE laugh heartily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holding the phone and talking to PUPKIN)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Mr. Pupkin, but Mr. Langford's secretary has no record of any appointment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pardon me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Langford's secretary has no record of any appointment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, technically speaking, I don't actually have an appointment. Jerry asked me to call him today and when I couldn't get through, I thought ... As PUPKIN talks, a VISITOR has entered and stands behind him waiting for the RECEPTIONIST's attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see.     (Into the phone) He says Mr. Langford    asked him to call. (To PUPKIN)     Mr. Langford's secretary wants to know    what this is in reference to. The RECEPTIONIST glances past PUPKIN to the VISITOR waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to PUPKIN)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you mind talking to her yourself? The RECEPTIONIST hands the phone to PUPKIN and occupies herself with the VISITOR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello? ... Jerry and I discussed my being on the show last night and he told me to call ... No. I don't mind. PUPKIN hands the phone back to the RECEPTIONIST.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm supposed to wait. The RECEPTIONIST listens to the phone for a moment and th hangs up. The VISITOR has just disappeared into the back offices. PUPKIN stands there, smiling politely at the RECEPTIONIST who returns a professional smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who was that gentleman?     (PUPKIN indicates with a glance to the entrance to the back offices that he is referring to the VISITOR)

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: Mr. Gangemi. PUPKIN draws a complete blank but wants to appear knowledgeable. PUPKIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I see.   Mr. Gangemi.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: He takes care of our air conditioning. CATHY LONG emerges from the back offices. She is a tall, modishly-dressed, attractive woman in her early thirties.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY LONG
dialogues.text: Uh ... Mr. Pupkin? PUPKIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: CATHY LONG
dialogues.text: I'm Cathy Long.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: I'm Mr. Pupkin.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY LONG
dialogues.text: Can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, but you are?

dialogues.speaker: CATHY LONG
dialogues.text: I'm Bert Thomas' assistant.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: Bert Thomas?

dialogues.speaker: CATHY LONG
dialogues.text: He's our executive producer.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: Oh, yes. I'm sure he is. But, you see, I've already talked directly with Jerry about my being on the show and he told me to get in touch with him. I'm just here to follow up on that.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY LONG
dialogues.text: What do you do, Mr. Pupkin? PUPKIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stand-up comedy. CATHY LONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine.    Where are you working?

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: Well, right now I'm developing new material.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY LONG
dialogues.text: I see. Well, as     soon as you start performing again,    let us know where you are and I'll    send my assistant down to check you    out.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: Sure. Sure. But that's not necessary, Miss Long. Jerry and I already went over all this.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY LONG
dialogues.text: Does Jerry know your work? PUPKIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding) Yes.    I don't think he does.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY LONG
dialogues.text: You don't happen to have a tape or a demo that we might listen to?

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: Oh, sure. I've got lots of tapes. That's no problem.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY LONG
dialogues.text: Good. Why don't you just send one to us and I assure you we'll listen to it promptly.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: Great. I'll do that. I can see that'd be a lot easier for Jerry. Thanks a lot, Miss Long.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY LONG
dialogues.text: Don't mention it, Mr. Pupkin.     Now, if you'd excuse me ... PUPKIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.    Sure. Thanks again. CATHY LONG leaves. PUPKIN, left standing there, smiles at the RECEPTIONIST who returns another professional smile.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: (to the RECEPTIONIST) Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: PUPKIN comes out of the building elated. He is immediatel confronted by MARSHA. PUPKIN continues to walk as MARSHA skips beside him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got to speak to you for a minute. I'm Marsha.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.   I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look. Did Jerry say anything about me last night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm really in a hurry, Marsha ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was he angry? ... In the car last night, I saw you. Did he talk about me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought that was you.     That was some stunt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did he say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We didn't talk about you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know Jerry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. MARSHA thrusts an envelope into PUPKIN's hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give him this for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I can't! Please. I need your help. You'll be my friend forever. Come on. I'll buy you something. What do you want? She takes a great messy bunch of bills out of her raincoa pockets and jams them into PUPKIN's hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take it.   I can get all I want. PUPKIN shrugs and pockets the money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.   I'll try.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning cold)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't try. Do it.       Remember.   We just made a deal. PUPKIN stares at the envelope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And don't open it.    It's private.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.   Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How soon can you get it to him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Couple a days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (menacingly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd better. MARSHA turns and walks in the direction from which they came. CAMERA FOLLOWS PUPKIN who walks on for a block or so, then opens the envelope. It contains a set of apartment keys, a scrap of hand-knitted woolen cloth and note in lipstick that reads: "I've made you a sweater, honey. Come try it on. I miss you. Love, M. 74 East 83rd Street, Apartment 2B!" He takes out the money

dialogues.speaker: MARSHA
dialogues.text: gave him. There are wads of tens, twenties and fifties with a sprinkling of fives and ones.
