dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: The hotel is just one step up from a flophouse. WE SEE PUPKIN enter.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: PUPKIN enters. WE SEE that it is a small room, furnished by the hotel in the plainest way. Nicely-done home-made collages of show business figures decorate the drab green walls. The room is neat and clean. PUPKIN goes directly to a plain table which holds two tape recorders -- one a small cassette the other a large table tape recorder. He picks up the microphone of the larger one and speaks into it. PUPKIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Testing.   Testing.   Testing. In the following montage, we hear in the background the replay of his "testing, testing testing" and various other noises -- a bit of his voice taped, a burst of laughter, the squeal of a tape recorder sent fast-forward a sudden burst of applause, a scrap of theme music. At th same time, the CAMERA PANS about the room.    We look at the collages which include all the obvious show busine figures, with a heavy emphasis on comedians from Chaplin and Keaton to Sid Caesar and Woody Allen. The collages also include such varied figures as Jimmy Carter, Julia Childs, Tom Seaver, David Brinkley, Muhammad Ali, Cliffor Irving, Walter Cronkite and Mark Spitz. There is a specia Kennedy section -- John F. and Bobby framed in black, Jackie in mourning and a picture of Teddy. There is also trio of assassins -- Sirhan, Oswald and James Earl Ray. There is also a talk show collage with a photo of Langfor in the center like a sun surrounded by Snyder, Walters, Carson and Griffin. One bookshelf holds a veritable library of comedy -- joke books, biographies of comedians treasuries of American humor. Another shelf holds scores of tapes in their own little boxes, each one neatly marke i.e., "LANGFORD MONOLOGUES:    7/5/72 to 9/9/72." "MISC. MONOLOGUES 6/13/68 to 8/1/69."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PUPKIN sitting before the tape recorder lost in thought. Finally, he starts the larger recorder and lifts the mike

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: First, Miss Long. Thanks very much for your help at the office and for passing this along to Jerry. I appreciate it more than you know. PUPKIN stops the tape recorder and thinks again for a few beats. He then starts the large recorder.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: Now, Jerry. Before I begin, I just want to thank you for listening to this material and for the opportunity that you've given me. You know, lots of people think that guys like you, you know, people who have made it, lose their feeling for struggling young talent such as myself. But now I know from experience that those people are just cynics, embittered by their own failure. I know, Jerry, that you're as human as the rest of us, if not more so. (pause) Oh well, I guess there's no point going on about it. You know how I feel. So let's get on with the show.   The best of Rupert Pupkin! I've sketched out this little introduction in order to save you a little time. So close your eyes and imagine it's exactly six o'clock. You're standing in the wings and we hear Rick Ross and the Orchestra strike up your theme song. PUPKIN pushes a button on the cassette and we hear the theme song of the Jerry Langford Show, followed by the voice of BERT CANTER, the announcer.

dialogues.speaker: BERT CANTER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: And now, direct from New York, it's the Jerry Langford Show! Tonight, with Jerry's special guest ... PUPKIN deftly shuts off the cassette and substitutes his own voice for that of CANTER's. The large tape recorder keeps rolling.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: ... the comedy find of the year making his television debut, Rupert Pupkin, the King of Comedy! PUPKIN rapidly races the cassette tape forward, then push down the "play" button. We hear a burst of thundering applause. PUPKIN lets the applause run for a while and then shuts it off. The large recorder keeps rolling.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: Now you come on, Jerry, and do your monologue. Then, when the time comes, this is how I see you introducing me. You'll say something like this. "Ladies and Gentlemen we're going to do something a little bit different tonight. It isn't often that you can call someone a sure thing in the entertainment business. After all, the verdict is always in your hands. But I think after you've met my next guest, that you'll agree with me that he's destined for greatness. So, now, will you please give your warmest welcome to the newest King of Comedy, Rupert Pupkin!!!" PUPKIN pushes the cassette and we hear another enormous burst of applause. PUPKIN lets it run, listening intently He stands up and faces a wall of his room, still holding the microphone. WE SEE that the wall is covered by a huge blow-up of an audience laughing and applauding.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: WE SEE a real audience laughing and applauding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PUPKIN strides triumphantly onto the stage, nodding to acknowledge the applause. He stops center stage as the television cameras maneuver about him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SHOT of the "APPLAUSE" sign flashing, then stopping. Still, the applause goes on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PUPKIN    raises his hands to quiet the audience. After a moments    the applause dies down, except for a pair of h in the    center of the orchestra. PUPKIN peers out to se who is    still applauding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RITA, in the middle of the audience, applauds enthusiastically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PUPKIN on stage.    PUPKIN gives RITA a special smile and nod.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will somebody tell that lovely lady that the applause sign is off. The audience laughs.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: PUPKIN stands facing the "audience" still holding the mik

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a possible introduction, Jerry. Now let's move on to my act.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: PUPKIN is pacing. He is wearing another suit, this one a broad-lapelled-grey. He is freshly shaved, is hair neatly combed, his shoes carrying a bright shine. He clutches a small flat box, neatly wrapped with the words 'FOR JERRY LANGFORD" written clearly across the top in large print. CATHY LONG emerges from one of the back corridors into th reception area.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suddenly a bit shy)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't want to take any chances with this ... uh ... Miss Long, so I ... uh ... thought I'd just bring it here myself. He hands CATHY LONG the package as though it contained nitroglycerine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We talked about this this morning, did we, Mr. ... ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pupkin.   Rupert Pupkin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes. It's been some day. (pause) Well, I certainly appreciate your bringing this over, Mr. Pupkin, and we'll listen to it as soon as possible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine. Er ... you don't have any idea how soon that might be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you can try checking with us tomorrow. We might know something by then. Otherwise, it'll have to be Monday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if I just sort of waited around here today, just in case? I'll stay out of the way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd just be wasting your time, Mr. Pupkin. We won't know anything until tomorrow at the earliest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I wouldn't consider it a waste of time at all.    I'd be glad to do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, why don't you try us tomorrow. Okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tomorrow? ... Right. I'll do that. Thanks a lot, Miss Long. And thank Jerry. CATHY LONG smiles at     PUPKIN and    goes, leaving PUPK staring at a picture     of LANGFORD    on the wall. WE F LANGFORD a moment and     PULL BACK    to see LANGFORD in PUPKIN would imagine     his office    to be.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: A large, corner office furnished in royal red, with high ceilings and a huge desk. Potted palms and hydrangeas res on a marble floor. LANGFORD is moving about restlessly, clutching PUPKIN's tape in one hand and waving it about. PUPKIN is seated on a comfortable couch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dynamite!    This is dynamite!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shyly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think so, Jerry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I've been at this for fifteen years, Rupert, and I haven't come up with anything like this -- not me, not any of my writers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling with obvious pleasure)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm glad you like it, Jerry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me something, Rube. (pause) How do you do it? I'm not asking to use the material myself. I just want to know how you (LANGFORD waves his arms in a gesture of frustration) how you do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I don't know if I can explain it, really.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on.    Try, Rube.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well,    it just sort of comes. I think about    my life, see, mainly about the worst    parts, all the awful things, and I just    try to see them in a funny light. That's    all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (eagerly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that what you do? The worst parts, and then you look at them in a funny light? Is that what you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More or less. It's hard to describe how its happens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But that's just it, Rube. It doesn't happen for me. Why do you think the show is in so much trouble? By the time I've done my monologue, everyone has switched to Carson. Maybe if you did a little writing ... ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, Jerry, I'd do anything I could to help out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You would? Great. Why don't you come out to my place this weekend and we'll hash it out. I'm having a few of my friends but we should be able to get a little work in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you mind if I brought someone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A girl, Rube?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A very special girl, Jerry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd love to meet her.

dialogues.speaker: THE HIGH-RISE OFFICE BUILDING ON UPPER BROADWAY
dialogues.text: PUPKIN emerges, lost in thought. Suddenly he notices MARSHA waiting nearby. She doesn't see PUPKIN. He sneaks off.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: It is a bright morning. LANGFORD, attempting to camouflag himself by wearing a cap over his eyes and his trench coa collar turned up, his eyes hidden behind dark glasses, walks out of the building. A DOORMAN is standing by the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cab, Jerry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's alright, thanks. WE FOLLOW LANGFORD as he walks. Some people don't notice. Others stare but leave him alone, a few commenting to the companions and pointing at him. A CAB DRIVER pulls alongside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Jerry. My brother can sing and juggle at the same time. How about puttin' him on your show? LANGFORD keeps walking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about it, Jerry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, I'm off duty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LANGFORD stands at the corner, next to a middle-aged COUPLE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're Jerry!! LANGFORD pulls his cap a little more tightly around his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know something.   (She giggles) I undress in front of you every night and Larry here doesn't mind at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't get anything started with her until you're off the air. Your show is ruining my sex life, Jerry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well then, you'll just have to put on a better show than I do.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: WE WATCH LANGFORD continue to walk, feeling what it is to be a celebrity out in public. After a few beats, we

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: WE SEE MARSHA trailing LANGFORD. LANGFORD notices her and starts walking quickly. MARSHA walks quickly. LANGFORD starts jogging. MARSHA starts jogging. Finally, LANGFORD breaks into a sprint. MARSHA runs after him. LANGFORD disappears into his office building. MARSHA arrives several seconds later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry!     God damnit! Just as MARSHA turns around, PUPKIN, unaware of her, walk cheerfully into the building.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: PUPKIN enters. The same middle-aged, plump RECEPTIONIST is seated behind the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir?     (recognizing him)   Oh, hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.   How are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to see Jerry, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are ... ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Pupkin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a minute. The RECEPTIONIST dials a number.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: Mr. Pupkin is here ... That's right ... (to PUPKIN) She'll be with you in a minute. PUPKIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who? RECEPTIONIST

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Long.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: But I wanted to see Jerry.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: Mr. Langford's not in. Miss Long will take care of you. PUPKIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright. PUPKIN paces for a few beats. He smiles at the RECEPTIONIST. A beat later, CATHY LONG comes out, carrying the tape in its box. CATHY LONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Pupkin?

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: How are you today?

dialogues.speaker: CATHY LONG
dialogues.text: Fine, Mr. Pupkin. Thank you for your tape. We listened to it with great interest. And, frankly, Mr. Pupkin, we saw a lot of good things in what you're doing. We feel you have good potential. Very good potential.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: (smiling) Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY LONG
dialogues.text: That's why I'll be honest with you, Mr. Pupkin ... PUPKIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: CATHY LONG
dialogues.text: We just don't think you're ready yet.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: (baffled) Not ready?

dialogues.speaker: CATHY LONG
dialogues.text: Well, we just don't feel right now that you're right for Jerry.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: (rapidly, half-listening) Right for Jerry. Sure.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY LONG
dialogues.text: Some of the material ... some of the one-liners, for instance ...

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: CATHY LONG
dialogues.text: ... were not very strong.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: You didn't care for some of the jokes, is that it?

dialogues.speaker: CATHY LONG
dialogues.text: That"s right.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: Good. Good. I can take care of that right way. Thanks. Just tell me the ones you think should go. That would be a big help. (to the RECEPTIONIST) This is great. (to CATHY LONG) Which ones?

dialogues.speaker: CATHY LONG
dialogues.text: Well, it's not just that, Mr. Pupkin. You see, Jerry likes to panel his guests, you know, chat with them afterwards.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: Sure.   Sure.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY LONG
dialogues.text: And frankly, we just don't feel you've got very much to talk about right now.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: But I've got my whole life to talk about!

dialogues.speaker: CATHY LONG
dialogues.text: Which is interesting to you, I'm sure and to your wife ... and to a few friends. But we feel that you should keep developing your act. Test it in some live situations. There are a number of clubs in the city you can try. And after a reasonable period, get in touch with us again and we'll be glad to send someone down to check out your progress. PUPKIN stares at her for a few moments as the tension gro

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: May I ask you a question, Miss Long? CATHY LONG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: Are you speaking for Jerry?

dialogues.speaker: CATHY LONG
dialogues.text: Let's put it this way, Mr. Pupkin. Mr. Langford has complete faith in our judgment.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: I'm sorry to have to say this, Miss Long, and I certainly don't want you to take it personally, but I have to tell you that I don't ... I don't have faith in your judgment.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY LONG
dialogues.text: Well, I'm sorry you feel that way, Mr. Pupkin. But I'm afraid there's nothing that can be done about that.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: No ... No ... I'm afraid I'll have to disagree with you again.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY LONG
dialogues.text: (with strained politeness) That's your privilege, Mr. Pupkin. Now, if you'll excuse me, please, I have some things to do. I'm sorry the news isn't better. CATHY LONG turns to go. PUPKIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Long? CATHY LONG turns back.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: When are you expecting Jerry in?

dialogues.speaker: CATHY LONG
dialogues.text: He won't be in until very late this afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: That's fine. Thank you. CATHY LONG stares at PUPKIN for a moment, glances at the RECEPTIONIST and then goes. PUPKIN takes a seat in the reception area. He smiles once more at the RECEPTIONIST. The RECEPTIONIST drops her eyes. A few beats go by. CATHY LONG passes by the entranceway and glances at PUPKIN. PUPKIN continues sitting there.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: Is there anyone else you would like to see?

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: That's alright. I'm happy just waiting. A few beats pass in silence.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: Well, would you mind waiting outside, please, Mr. Pupkin? This is a reception area, not a waiting room.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: I understand. PUPKIN remains seated. A few more moments pass. Several OFFICE PERSONNEL pass by the entranceway and glance at PUPKIN. After a few more beats, a large, plainly-dressed MAN in his mid-fifties emerges from the back offices. He goes over to PUPKIN, who stands.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICIAL
dialogues.text: Mr. Pupkin? I'm Raymond Wirtz, in charge of security for the Langford organization. WIRTZ puts his arm on PUPKIN's shoulder and, as the following dialogue unfolds leads him out the door, down the corridor and into the elevator.

dialogues.speaker: WIRTZ
dialogues.text: Now I think you understand that we have certain rules here that are essential to the smooth functioning of our operation. PUPKIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.     Sure.

dialogues.speaker: WIRTZ
dialogues.text: And that without these rules, we really wouldn't be able to function at our best. You follow my point? PUPKIN nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now one of these rules is that only authorized personnel and those having official business with our organization are permitted on our premises. And that's why I'm asking you, Mr. Pupkin, to cooperate with us. They have reached the elevator and WIRTZ has pushed the button.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want me to leave the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right. It's nothing personal, Mr. Pupkin. Just doing my job. The elevator arrives. WIRTZ signals with his head that PUPKIN should enter. PUPKIN gets in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have a pleasant day.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: PUPKIN comes out and takes up a position outside the door preparing to wait for LANGFORD. MARSHA sees him and comes over to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, did you give it to him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (out of a daze)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you get my letter to him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not in there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, if you don't want to give it him, okay. I'll get somebody else. But don't try to con me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you I'd try and I will. I'm going to wait for him right here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me the envelope, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, but ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw him go in myself!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But they said he wasn't in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just give me the envelope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When did he go in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ten minutes ago! That's when.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I saw him my ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he hasn't come out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been standing right here.      Now how about it? PUPKIN turns and goes back into the building.       MARSH after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm staying right here!

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: PUPKIN enters briskly and goes up to the RECEPTIONIST.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with authority)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell Jerry Langford I'm here, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, sir. Mr. Langford's not in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I happen to know he is.      So would you please tell him I'm here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.   He's not in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're putting your job on the line, lady. The RECEPTIONIST starts making a call inside. PUPKIN glances at her and walks right in to the inner corridors. He starts peering into the open doors of the offices that line the corridor. The whole place is like a gigantic maze. OFFICE PERSONNEL pass by him, taking no notice of him. He continues wandering around desperately, completel lost. A few beat later, he spots WIRTZ leading a pair of SECURITY GUARDS. PUPKIN keeps peering into offices quickl as he flees. The GUARDS and WIRTZ finally catch up to PUPKIN at the steno pool and, after a brief chase around the pool, they catch PUPKIN and subdue him. They start dragging him out past the eyes of the OFFICE PERSONNEL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling as he is dragged)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry! Jerry! (to WIRTZ) You're going the have a hell of a lot of explaining to do! (calling) Jerry!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You had your warning, Mr. Krupkin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry!   Help me. Jerry!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A CLOSE-UP of PUPKIN as he is dragged out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (screaming)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry!

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: WE WATCH the SECURITY GUARDS and WIRTZ pitch PUPKIN out into the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we see your face again, Mr. Pupkin, we'll call the police.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Start looking for a new job! MARSHA comes straight up to PUPKIN who is brushing himsel off. His eyes are glazed and distant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does he have it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (abstractedly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry. I'll get it to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?   When? There is a pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This weekend. He asked me to go out there, to his house.

dialogues.speaker: THE BAR-RESTAURANT WHERE RITA WORKS
dialogues.text: PUPKIN enters the bar-restaurant. Through the window WE SEE him talking to RITA. He is voluble, animated. She looks skeptical, with a wry smile on her face. Finally WE WATCH him extract an answer from her. She shrugs, smiles and says yes. He comes walking out the door, his hounded expression softened by a smile.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: WE WATCH PUPKIN getting fitted in a new suit, attended by a SALESMAN and a TAILOR.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: WE WATCH PUPKIN buy a suitcase.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: WE WATCH PUPKIN perusing the beautiful diamond, sapphire, and emerald rings and we take a few moments to PAN OVER these beautiful jewels as he sees them. Finally, he picks out a splendid ring with a single, middle-sized sapphire and hands a surprised SALESLADY the money in cash.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: PUPKIN and RITA are seated side by side. Since it is Saturday morning, the train is sparsely populated. A CONDUCTOR has just finished taking PUPKIN's tickets. RITA is edgy. PUPKIN is strangely calm and a little remote. He is wearing his new suit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are we going to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (patiently)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I told you, I've got some work to discuss with him. That's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But what about me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's fine, but while you two are talking, what am I going to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can chat with the other guests.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure they'll be thrilled hearing about the wonderful world of draft beer. (pause) Let's tell 'em I'm a model, okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If they ask what I do, let's just say I model. You don't mind pretending just a little, do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If it make you feel better. There is a pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is    a gas! Too bad nobody'll believe    it. (pause) After you guys are done    working, what happens? Are we going    out someplace, or what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure Jerry has something arranged. There is another pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do    these people do for fun? Do they    party or do freaky things or just    get drunk or ... I mean, What do    they do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess they just sit around and talk and enjoy each other's company, like anybody else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Talk?!? What can you talk about for three or four hours?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do    you mean? They've got plenty to talk    about. They do things.    All kinds of    interesting things happen to them    and then they talk about them. What do    you think Jerry's show is all about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, a cocktail party with no drinks. That's what all those shows are. At least they help you get to sleep. There is a pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (glumly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy, this is going to be some great weekend.   I thought we were gonna have some fun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just take it easy, Rita.     Everything's going to be fine. WE MOVE IN for a CLOSE-UP of PUPKIN who is fading out.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: It is a large white house with colonial columns set in th middle of a palatial estate whose rolling lawns are punctuated with fine old trees. We circle around to the back where LANGFORD, a handful of his FRIENDS (which can familiar television celebrities) and PUPKIN and RITA are just finishing a lavish lunch on the patio. A pair of SERVANTS are clearing the table and serving the coffee an desert as the scene unfolds. As we arrive, we hear a loud burst of laughter. PUPKIN is regaling the COMPANY with stories.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: Oh, you have no idea how bad it's gotten in New York. Now the muggers are so efficient that, each time they jump you, they take your name and address and put you on a mailing list. (the COMPANY chuckles) And once you're on the list, you're in real trouble, like this friend of mine who was mugged thirty-two times on his way home from work. (a little laughter from the COMPANY) A SERVANT places the desert, a little, elegant tart, in front of PUPKIN and RITA.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: (to SERVANT) Thanks. The SERVANT smiles. As PUPKIN continues his story, he glances occasionally at RITA who has begun to nibble at h tart. PUPKIN also glances conspiratorially at LANGFORD who smiles back.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: So what my friend does is get himself a dog, one of those huge German Shepherds. One night, he's walking the dog in Central Park when he hears this voice behind him. (in a German accent) Okay, Harry, drop your vallet and keep your hantz over your head or I bite your little fanny off. The COMPANY breaks up.

dialogues.speaker: ONE GUEST
dialogues.text: (to LANGFORD) Looks like you've found yourself a winner, Jerry.

dialogues.speaker: LANGFORD
dialogues.text: (looking at PUPKIN) He's the one who found himself a winner. RITA looks up, smiles and blushes. The rest of the COMPAN smiles benignly and grows attentive as RITA returns to eating her tart. Suddenly she bites down on something hard. She fishes it out of her mouth and looks at it. The COMPANY giggles. It is the ring PUPKIN purchased at Cartier's. The COMPANY applauds lightly and laughs. LANGFORD lifts his wine glass.

dialogues.speaker: LANGFORD
dialogues.text: To Rita and Rupert -- a short engagement and a long, happy marriage. The COMPANY drinks with murmurs of "Hear! Hear!"   RITA and PUPKIN beam. RITA looks lovingly at PUPKIN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (the PUPKIN)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you set a date?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking pointedly at LANGFORD)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope we're all invited.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone's invited.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: The theater is packed. World Series bunting hangs from th balcony and the front of the stage. We hear RICK ROSS and the ORCHESTRA strike up Mendelssohn's Wedding March.   Do one aisle walks RITA, accompanied by the MAN whom PUPKIN hit over the head at the bar. Down the other aisle marche PUPKIN, accompanied by LANGFORD. The AUDIENCE cheers wildly. The two COUPLES walk to the stage where a white- haired OFFICIAL awaits them. BERT CANTER stands at his side. PUPKIN and RITA disengage from their ESCORTS and stand before the OFFICIAL. The music stops and the AUDIENCE grows quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are met here in these extraordinary circumstances to join this man and this woman in holy wedlock. But, before we begin, let me voice a personal word of thanks to you, Rupert and to you, Rita, for choosing me to perform this prestigious ceremony. Because we are on prime time, I am going to discard my customary remarks in favor of a few personal reflections.   When I was principal at Clifton High and these two were students, I had very little faith that Rupert here would amount to very much. But like his teachers and his fellow students, I underestimated this fine young man.   Some say that this misjudgment is directly tied to my recent dismissal as head of the Clifton School System. But let me take this opportunity to set the record straight. Knowing that Rupert and Rita here were most certainly destined for a great career and a lifetime of happiness, I voluntarily stepped down. I would only here add my own wishes to those of millions of viewers for their continued health, wealth and boundless success. The OFFICIAL looks quickly past RITA and PUPKIN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll be back to marry them in a minute, right after this word.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: PUPKIN and RITA are seated as they were.      We hear the CONDUCTOR calling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Greenwich.    Greenwich next stop. Greenwich. PUPKIN and RITA grab their small suitcases and quickly mo down the aisle towards the door.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: RITA is peering out the window.     PUPKIN is still lost thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at that one. How'd you like to live in that?!?! Or that one! What do you figure these run? The taxi stops in front of a walled lot behind which is visible a handsome English stucco home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to DRIVER)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's gorgeous! PUPKIN is genuinely puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to DRIVER)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, friend, I wouldn't want to tell you how many times I made this trip.   (pause)    That'll be three seventy-five. PUPKIN, still puzzled, hands him a five dollar bill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (abstractedly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep it. The DRIVER gets out and puts PUPKIN and RITA's bags, which he had stacked on the front seat, onto the sidewalk

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. If you need a ride back, just ask the guy for Wayne. That's me. The CAMERA PULLS BACK as PUPKIN opens the gate and he and RITA walk up the drive.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: PUPKIN and RITA stand before the front door. PUPKIN rings After a few beats, the door is opened by an Indonesian HOUSEBOY. PUPKIN walks in right past him, RITA following behind.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: PUPKIN hands the HOUSEBOY the two suitcases as he talks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must be Jonno. I'm Rupert Pupkin and this is Rita Keane. Mr. Langford's expecting us. Jonno nods politely but uncertainly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (uncertain)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Langford asked you to come?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right. Would you mind taking those up? Jerry and I have some work that may oblige me to stay overnight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Mr. Langford's not here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out playing golf, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still puzzled and unsure)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe he'll finally break a hundred.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe it's better if you came back ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's alright. We don't mind waiting. PUPKIN walks from the foyer into the living-room, leaving JONNO staring after him holding the bags. RITA walks into the living room after PUPKIN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (worried)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The table's only set for one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's from breakfast.     Relax, will you?

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: JONNO is on the phone.   A black lady COOK stands at his side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into the phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me talk to Jerry Langford please ... I know he is ... It's important.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: It is a handsomely furnished room, done in old American antiques and other tasteful pieces. There is a grand pian heavy with pictures in one corner and wall-to-wall bookshelves that are mostly full and mixed with a balance of classics and modern popular reading. The whole room marks LANGFORD as a man of discernment. The shelves also house a fine stereo and a small, discreet bar. RITA and PUPKIN walk in like strangers in paradise, awed by the obvious elegance and expense the room reflects.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as though he owned it)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you like it?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (admiringly) I could live here.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: (smiling proudly) It's the only way to live. RITA stands in the center of the room, ill at ease, while PUPKIN strolls about comfortably, picking up an ashtray here, a cigarette case there, inspecting the artifacts fo inscriptions, clues, hints about LANGFORD's character and life.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: How come he isn't here?

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: You heard the guy.     He's out playing golf.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Didn't you tell him when we'd get here? PUPKIN continues to move about the room, fielding RITA's suspicious inquiries effortlessly.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: We didn't have time to iron out the details. Now just relax. We're the first guests, that's all.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (interrupting) That Jonno character hadn't even heard of us!

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: (a little irritated) It probably slipped Jerry's mind. He has better things to think about than what he tells his houseboy.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: It's just not time way I expected it, that's all. There is a pause. PUPKIN continues his investigation. has moved to the grand piano in the rear of the room.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: What do we do now? PUPKIN is looking    at a picture of an American Gothic c standing in front    of a wood-frame house. As he comment the pictures, the    CAMERA PANS over them. They form a k of slide-show of    LANGFORD's life.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: These are Jerry's parents. His father runs the Post office in Wolverine -- that's in North Dakota. PUPKIN then fixes on a picture of an eleven-year-old boy standing next to a puppet stage with a puppet (obviously held by the boy) staring at its master.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: This one was in Newsweek. He started giving these puppet shows when he was still in grade school. WE SEE a picture of a very young LANGFORD seated before a microphone with some celebrity.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: And this is from his quiz show in St. Louis. Can you believe it? RITA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure I can.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: That was the name of the show. WE MOVE to a picture of LANGFORD smiling at JACK PAAR.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: And here's when he wrote for Jack Paar. He made a hundred and fifty a week and look at him now. Another picture of LANGFORD with a group of women sitting in a studio.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: And this is his morning show. A picture of LANGFORD standing in a park with his two boy eleven and eight.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: And his kids. He's divorced. RITA, who has been only half-listening, has picked up a small, beautifully enameled cigarette box.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Look at this. I love these kind of things. Look at the work.   I've got this thing about boxes. RITA puts it down reluctantly, picks it up, then puts it down again.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: JONNO is holding the phone, waiting.     The COOK stands, looking at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Langford? ... I'm sorry to disturb you ...

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: RITA has just finished fixing herself a drink. She takes large sip and starts pacing around. PUPKIN is seated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much longer are we gonna have to wait?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Until he gets back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do we have to just sit here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He should be back pretty soon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doesn't he have any music or anything? Let's get a little life into this place. It's like a funeral parlor. She walks over to the stereo and opens the cupboard benea it, revealing rows and rows of records.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is more like it. She pulls out a record.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Rita.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, yourself. She puts the record on. Frank Sinatra starts singing "The Can't Take That Away From Me." She takes a big sip of her drink, puts it down and comes over to PUPKIN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about a little spin, handsome?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pulling back)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here? RITA snuggles into PUPKIN and starts dancing him around. He resists feebly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Rupert.      I came up here for a good time. PUPKIN gives in and starts      dancing with her in the the 1950's, elbow out, arm      up, box step. After a moments, PUPKIN closes his      eyes. He has reached a of perfect bliss, his dream      girl in is arms. They silently as we hear Sinatra      singing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The way you wore your hat, The way we danced till three, The memory of all that -- Oh no, they can't take that away from me, No ... they can't take that away ... from ... me. The orchestra plays.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You never could dance, could you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How would you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh I danced with you a couple of times -- at the Sigma U party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were there with Tommy Winston.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't ask me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the one time I did ask you and you went with him anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I couldn't go with you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be serious, Rupert.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: JONNO stands a few feet from the kitchen door, staring at RITA and PUPKIN dancing in the living room, an unbelievin anxious expression on his face.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: The music has stopped momentarily and PUPKIN and RITA disengage. PUPKIN looks lovingly at RITA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's all ended happily and that's what counts. RITA grows jumpy under his gaze.      She looks around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wonder what the rest of this place looks like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure it's all very nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gaily)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, there's only one way to find out. RITA scampers over to the stairs and pauses on the first step.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You coming or not? RITA bounds up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rita! CAMERA FOLLOWS PUPKIN up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: There is no sign of RITA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you? There is no answer. CAMERA FOLLOWS PUPKIN from room to room. They are all guest rooms, neat, pretty, clean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Rita. This isn't funny. Finally, PUPKIN opens the door to another room.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: It is clearly LANGFORD's bedroom with a few clothes strew about, and other signs of being lived in. RITA lies on th bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shocked)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing, Rita?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love it! All those millions of women out there dying to change places with me right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on.   We shouldn't be here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Relax, will you. Let me have a little fun, for Christ's sake. RITA gets off the bed and runs into the john.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at this. It's nicer than my whole apartment. PUPKIN enters the large, beautifully done bathroom.   RIT examines her face in the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (urgently)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go, Rita.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy, I really need some sun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rita, this is Jerry's ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lay off, will you, Rupert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But we have no right ... RITA picks up a can of shave cream and squirts a large dollop in PUPKIN's face. WE COME IN for a CLOSE UP of PUPKIN's face, buried under shaving cream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That wasn't funny, Rita. RITA hands him a towel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here. She looks around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now for something that smells nice. She swings open the cabinet with a flourish. The door swings open violently and the mirror shatters against something as pills and bottles tumble into the sink. PUPKIN and RITA stand there, staring at each other. RITA begins to laugh, but her laugh is cut short by the slam o the downstairs door.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: LANGFORD has entered, drawn and businesslike.       JONNO the COOK have moved out to greet him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking around)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was going to call the police but then I thought to myself 'what if they are Mr. Langford's friends?' We hear some whispers and scuffling at the top of the stairs. LANGFORD, JONNO and the COOK look up. PUPKIN comes bounding down the stairs jauntily with RITA followi cautiously behind. PUPKIN has large traces of shaving cream behind his ears and on his neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Jerry.   We were just freshening up. PUPKIN stops at the base of the stairs, turns around, and waves RITA down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to RITA)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Rita. No need to be shy. PUPKIN smiles conspiratorially at LANGFORD.       RITA co slowly down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry, I'd like you to meet Rita Keane. Rita, say hello to Jerry!

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (tentatively) Pleased to meet you. LANGFORD nods imperceptibly, his face tense, his eyes alert. RITA, reading her frigid reception, looks to PUPKIN who walks blithely past LANGFORD into the living room, toward the bar.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: What's your pleasure? PUPKIN glances at the small mess he has left on the bar a turns back to LANGFORD who has moved into the living room with JONNO and the COOK a few steps behind. PUPKIN flashe LANGFORD an apologetic smile.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: (to LANGFORD) We've already taken the liberty, so to speak. Rita was a little nervous. It isn't every day she meets someone like you.

dialogues.speaker: LANGFORD
dialogues.text: What's going on here?

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: We've been sitting around, waiting. That's all. How was your golf game?

dialogues.speaker: JONNO
dialogues.text: I told them you weren't here.

dialogues.speaker: COOK
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: He did, Jerry. He was very helpful. We had to take an early train. There was nothing else until after one. (pause) I brought the material. It's upstairs, in my bags. (pause) Where is everybody?

dialogues.speaker: LANGFORD
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: The other guests! (in a confidential tone) We're getting a little hungry, to tell you the truth.

dialogues.speaker: LANGFORD
dialogues.text: (as though confirming what PUPKIN said) You are.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: (backing off) But we don't mind waiting, do we, Rita? RITA says nothing. She has sensed something terribly wrong and is slowly backing away from PUPKIN.

dialogues.speaker: LANGFORD
dialogues.text: You know, I could have you arrested, both of you.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: (seizing the idea) You know you could! And there'd be absolutely no way we could prove we belonged here. I never thought of that.

dialogues.speaker: LANGFORD
dialogues.text: Well, you should have before you ...

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: (still fixed on the idea) Maybe we could work up a routine about that, about a guy who throws all his friends in jail. Let's talk about that.

dialogues.speaker: LANGFORD
dialogues.text: (sharply) Let's not.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: Sure, Jerry. Whatever you ...

dialogues.speaker: LANGFORD
dialogues.text: (exasperated) Look, if you've got something for me to sign, let's have it and get it over with so I can get back ...

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: (interrupting) That wouldn't be right, Jerry. Not in your own house!

dialogues.speaker: LANGFORD
dialogues.text: (summoning his last bit of patience) I have a lot of work to get to. (to JONNO) How did they get here?

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: We took a taxi, Jerry ... But don't worry about us. You go ahead and do your work and we'll just take a stroll around until lunch is ready.

dialogues.speaker: LANGFORD
dialogues.text: You're a little thick, aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: (smiling as though complimented) Well, maybe a ...

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: What's he's saying, Rupert, is that he wants us out.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: Don't listen to her, Jerry. She doesn't understand anything about us.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Don't get me into this.

dialogues.speaker: LANGFORD
dialogues.text: (to JONNO) Call the station. JONNO goes back into the foyer, followed by the COOK.

dialogues.speaker: LANGFORD
dialogues.text: There'll be a cab here in a few minutes. Now if you'll just wait at the gate ...

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: Look, Jerry, if I've said anything out of line, let's chalk it up to inexperience, okay? I'll just go upstairs and get my tape and we can start working. It shouldn't take long and then you'll have the rest of the afternoon to yourself.

dialogues.speaker: LANGFORD
dialogues.text: I've told you just as clearly as I can. I want you out of here and I want you out now. Scram, beat it, vamoose, out! Is that plain enough! RITA deftly pockets the enamel box.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: But what about my material?    When are we going to go over it?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Come on, Rupert, the man wants us to go.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: Tell her she's wrong, Jerry!

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Look, Mr. Langford. I didn't know anything about all this. I hardly know this guy. I haven't seen him in years.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: Rita!

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: So if there's anything I can do, any way I can make this up to you.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: She's nothing, Jerry. She's just some girl who works in a bar. Don't let her spoil things. LANGFORD starts herding RITA and PUPKIN towards the door. LANGFORD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on.   Let's go.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: All I'm asking is fifteen minutes. That's all. Just long enough to listen to my act. Is that asking too much -- fifteen minutes of your day against my whole life?

dialogues.speaker: LANGFORD
dialogues.text: I'll call the police if I have to. LANGFORD realizes he is being hard.    He stops for a mom

dialogues.speaker: LANGFORD
dialogues.text: I have my own life, that's all.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: But what about me, Jerry? What about my life? I made plans -- based on what you said. You can't just turn your back on me.

dialogues.speaker: LANGFORD
dialogues.text: I'm not telling you again. There is a long pause as the truth finally sinks in. PUPK just stares at LANGFORD with disbelief that turns to ange

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: So this is the way it   works when you're big, huh? You    just play with people. Is that part    of the kick, Jerry? (pause) I can     see I was all wrong about you. All    wrong. RITA starts tugging at PUPKIN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Rupert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to RITA)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up! (to LANGFORD) You weren't my friend at all, were you? You were just playing some kind of game with me. Well, that's not going to stop me, Jerry. I'm just going to work a little bit harder, that's all, use a little bit more enterprise. And not count on anybody. That's where I made my mistake. I can see that now. PUPKIN picks up the pair of small suitcases.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (glaring at LANGFORD)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Rita. We're wasting our time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PUPKIN strides out with RITA following.     She casts LAN an apologetic glance as she goes. The     door slams behi them. They walk down the path silently     for a few mome as the CAMERA PULLS UP, following them    in an OVERHEAD We hear them start talking as they make    their way towa the gate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (baffled and angry)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you think was going to happen? You think he'd just ... ? What's the matter with you? (pause) You can't just walk into a guy's house! And what about me? What did you ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting in a calm but firm voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up, Rita. I'm thinking.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: MARSHA sits at the wheel of this lavishly appointed sedan her face made up as though she were going to a fancy part PUPKIN sits on the other side of the front seat. His ex- pression has changed somewhat from the PUPKIN we have see He is less wide-eyed, less innocent, tougher.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHA
dialogues.text: (whining) How much longer?!?

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: Do you want him or not? There is a pause.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHA
dialogues.text: You sure he's in there? PUPKIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Certain.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHA
dialogues.text: (with obvious delight) My parents are going to be furious! PUPKIN pulls a toy revolver from his jacket pocket and lo it over. MARSHA glances at it.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHA
dialogues.text: It looks real.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: That's the whole point. (gesturing with his head towards the entrance of the building which is some 50 yards away) Pay attention. MARSHA looks towards the entrance.   A few beats pass.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHA
dialogues.text: What if he doesn't come down? PUPKIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He will.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHA
dialogues.text: But what if he doesn't?

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: We'll come back tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHA
dialogues.text: And wait again?

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: Look, you're going to have him all to yourself. What else do you want? A MAN resembling LANGFORD walks out the entrance. PUPKIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that him?!?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure I'm sure. That looks too much like him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When it's him it doesn't look like him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep watching. PUPKIN closes his eyes and rests for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's him. PUPKIN's eyes snap open. WE SEE LANGFORD, concealed in hi trench coat, dark glasses and tightly pulled cap start wa east.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What should I do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a second and follow him.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: LANGFORD is walking innocently towards his offices. Mercedes prowls a quarter of a block behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too busy.   Keep going.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: LANGFORD continues walking.      The street is practicall empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go past him and stop.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: WE STAY with LANGFORD as he walks.  WE SEE the Mercedes pull past him. Suddenly PUPKIN is IN THE FRAME, walking side by side with LANGFORD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just keep walking or I'll kill you right here. LANGFORD looks at PUPKIN in terror.        He falters a b of fear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said keep walking. This is a gun in my pocket and I've got nothing to lose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (who keeps walking)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just keep walking and don't talk to anybody. I'll tell you what to do. A MAN    coming the other way stops and stares at LANGFOR out of    curiosity. PUPKIN and LANGFORD keep walking. Th get to    where the Mercedes is waiting. PUPKIN jabs LANG in the    ribs with the gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get in!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, this is ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just shut up and get in. LANGFORD gets in the front seat.     PUPKIN follows.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: LANGFORD moves to the middle of the front seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Jerry. LANGFORD looks over and recognizes MARSHA.        A CLOSE records his reaction of sheer terror.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: WE SEE LANGFORD get out of the Mercedes which is parked i front of a fire hydrant. LANGFORD follows MARSHA into a brownstone. PUPKIN walks behind LANGFORD.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: PUPKIN, LANGFORD and MARSHA enter. It is an absolutely stunning studio apartment, furnished lavishly by Marsha's parents for their daughter in antique furniture suitable for a woman of fifty. MARSHA has imprinted her own stamp on the apartment in two ways: First, the place is abso- lutely chaotic. Secondly, there are a number of blow-up pictures on the wall. A picture of LANGFORD sits on the bureau. There is a big brass bed with an ornate brass frame at the foot. LANGFORD stares at MARSHA and PUPKIN. PUPKIN closes the blinds and turns on the lights. MARSHA trains the gun on LANGFORD. PUPKIN finishes his work and takes the gun back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't like being so rough out there, Jerry. But I wanted you to know that I meant business. I didn't want anything happening to you over some misunderstanding. LANGFORD just stares at him, frozen with fear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now I know you're wondering    what this is all about. Actually     you've got nothing to worry about.     You just do what I tell you and    by, say, midnight, you'll be safe and    out of here. Of course if you try     anything clever, I'll kill you -- or    Marsha will. She knows how to use     this too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You realize what you're saying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Jerry. This isn't a spur of the moment thing.    Give me a little credit, will you. PUPKIN looks over to a small phone table with a chair nex to it. He motions to it with his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to LANGFORD)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sit down. LANGFORD docilely sits by the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, you're going to call your office and tell them this: that unless a man who identifies himself as the King is allowed on the show tonight as the first guest, they'll never see you alive again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll say it again ...

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: It is a large office in two pieces. A SECRETARY sits in the smaller part next to the door of the larger section. Her phone is ringing. She answers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bert Thomas! ... He's in a meeting, Mr. Langford ... I see.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: THOMAS, a young, trim executive in his late thirties, in modish dress, sits at the table with several other PEOPLE including CATHY LONG. They are sipping coffee from con- tainers. There are memos and lists and other papers on the table. The SECRETARY stands at the doorway. THOMAS and the others are looking up at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He says it's urgent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah? Well, tell him I'll call him back. (to the others) It's that Martino kid, the impressionist.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: LANGFORD sits by the phone with PUPKIN a few steps away, holding the gun and MARSHA looking on. LANGFORD looks desperate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then try again!

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: An irked BERT THOMAS wearily picks up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah? ... Okay, Martino, let's stop the bullshit ... what? ... Okay, I'm listening. WE WATCH THOMAS' expression as it turns from skepticism to concern bordering on alarm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me that again? ... Wait a minute. What do we call our second cameraman?

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: The scene is as before, only now LANGFORD is sweating a b

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into the phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helen Keller.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (warning)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No tricks, Jerry.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: THOMAS is still at the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't do anything, Jerry.     Stay right there. Tell him we'll do     anything he wants. Tell him to cool     it. Are you okay? ... Look, tell him    to call us about five, okay. We'll     let him know what to do. And don't do     anything stupid. THOMAS puts down the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calls to his SECRETARY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vivien! THOMAS' SECRETARY appears at the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get me the number of the F.B.I. right away. And get me Crockett's office. And keep your mouth shut about this.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: LANGFORD is standing awkwardly in the middle of the room, wearing a sweater that matches the patch of cloth we saw in the envelope MARSHA gave PUPKIN. PUPKIN is still training his pistol on LANGFORD and MARSHA is appraising the fit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to PUPKIN)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to LANGFORD)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had to guess on the sleeves. (to PUPKIN) He gets to keep it, doesn't he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, if he isn't dead.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: THOMAS is on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (panicky)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know he's in a meeting and I don't care. I've got to talk to him! ... No, he can not call me back. Don't you understand? This is an emergency

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: LANGFORD is seated on a chair whose back is pressed right up against the high, ornate brass bedstead at the foot of the bed. MARSHA trains the gun on LANGFORD now. PUPKIN is unpacking a suitcase. He takes out a handsome blue sui ruffled shirt, a bow tie, black shoes, underwear, socks, shaving equipment, soap, a hairbrush, a clothesbrush, a small shoe shine kit, aftershave lotion, deodorant and a dozen or so rolls of inch-and-a-half wide adhesive tape. He removes this stuff from a suitcase that is barely big enough to hold it -- so the mere packing of all this para phernalia into such a small space represents something of achievement. As he takes the stuff out, he talks to LANGFORD, his back turned to him.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: This wasn't an easy decision for me, Jerry, believe me. For one thing, I knew it meant we could never be friends again and that hurt me. It's hard to lose a friend, even one who has let you down. You always hope you can patch things up. You know, a guy like me doesn't make friends that easily. PUPKIN pauses a moment, then turns to LANGFORD, his voice filled with emotion.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: Why didn't you just listen to the tape when I asked you? Then I wouldn't have to be doing all this. Was it really too much to expect -- a few minutes of your time to listen to something I'd worked on my whole life? LANGFORD's eyes shift rapidly.   He is obviously calculat how to deal with PUPKIN.

dialogues.speaker: LANGFORD
dialogues.text: (with disarming charm) Hey, if that's what's bothering you, let's go over to my office and listen to that tape right now.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: Are you crazy, Jerry? Do you know what would happen to me? MARSHA listens to this exchange a bit nervously.   Gestur to her gun, she says:

dialogues.speaker: MARSHA
dialogues.text: Am I going to have to hold this thing all day? PUPKIN sees she has lowered it practically to her side.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: (to MARSHA) Just keep it on him. (to LANGFORD) You know, Jerry. Friendship is a two- way street. All that time I was worrying about you and your ratings and everything, you couldn't have cared less about me. LANGFORD thinks rapidly for a beat or two.

dialogues.speaker: LANGFORD
dialogues.text: You're right. You know that? I was thoughtless. It's just that when you're doing a big show, it's hard to tell who your friends really are. I was wrong. I apologize. Why don't we just shake hands and forget the whole thing?

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: (suspiciously) That's easy to say, Jerry.

dialogues.speaker: LANGFORD
dialogues.text: But I mean it. I'll tell     them that the whole thing was a joke    and then we can go to my office and    listen to that tape. Come on. What      do you say? LANGFORD rises with his hand extended toward PUPKIN.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHA
dialogues.text: (to LANGFORD, sharply) Sit down! LANGFORD looks to PUPKIN.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHA
dialogues.text: I said sit! LANGFORD reluctantly sits down.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: (to MARSHA) What's the matter?     You heard what he said.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHA
dialogues.text: All of a sudden, with a gun on him, he wants to make up and be friends. And, once he's out the door, what happens then?

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: What happens then, Jerry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You get to his office and they jump you, that's what happens, Rupert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's right, Jerry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not if I tell them not to. This is Jerry, Rupert, I give you my word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to MARSHA)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gives me his word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah? And what else? Come on, Rupert, I'm sick of waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what else, Jerry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Rupert. My word's good enough, isn't it. PUPKIN stares at LANGFORD for a few beats. Then he shakes his head sadly and says in a very quiet, discouraged voic

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Jerry. It's not. (to MARSHA) Keep the gun up! PUPKIN comes over to LANGFORD with a few rolls of adhesiv tape in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry to do it this way, Jerry, but I'm no good at knots. Just put your arms up and out, okay? LANGFORD spreads his arms back against the brass bedstead As PUPKIN goes to tape them, LANGFORD tries to grab him, but, with sudden, demonic force, PUPKIN pins him against the bedstead. They are practically nose to nose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no, Jerry. None of that.      Now hold still.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: We are in the office of WILSON CROCKETT, president of the National Broadcasting Network. CROCKETT sits behind his desk, facing a group which includes several other NETWORK

dialogues.speaker: EXECUTIVES, BERT THOMAS, CATHY LONG, F.B.I. INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: PATTEN, and his assistant, GIARDELLO.   They are in the midst of debate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I tell you, the bureau is doing everything possible to locate Mr. Langford. Right now our men are out checking out every radical group in this city.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Radical?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're willing to sacrifice their leader in order to get their message across, aren't they? You've got to figure that this is a desperate outfit. I don't know who they are anymore than you do. But I do know I've got to stop them. Otherwise, what you're seeing here is just the first of a whole wave of these kinds of kidnappings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (upset)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does this mean we're not supposed to put him on?!?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who am I addressing, please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's Bert Thomas. He produces the show.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm only saying, Mr. Thomas, that we can't allow this to reach the public. When the kidnappers call in, of course you're going to be cooperative. Promise them anything they want. After all, this King character is going to have to show up sooner or later. And once we get our hands on him, he'll tell us where Mr. Langford is. PATTEN grinds his fist into his palm.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: WE SEE PUPKIN in the shower, shampooing.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: The scene is as before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. Let him go on if you have to. It's just a taping. You can always erase him afterwards, can't you? (pause) All I'm saying is this: don't put him on the air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's fine, Inspector, but let's say he finishes his bit and you've worked him over ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Questioned him, Mr. Thomas. There is light laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, questioned him and he still won't talk. We get to eleven thirty and what do we do? Do we air him or what? There is a heavy pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would say no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But they might kill Jerry!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (breaking in)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Burt. (to PATTEN) Thank you, Inspector. We appreciate your position and we'll do all we can to cooperate with you.   But I have to tell you right now that, if it comes down to it, we're not taking any chances with Mr. Langford's life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand but ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If your men haven't been able to locate Mr. Langford by air time, we're going to have to put this King guy on, no matter what he's said. After all, Inspector, what's ten or fifteen minutes of talk show time against a man's life?

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: WE SEE PUPKIN in his new suit and ruffled shirt, impeccab groomed, standing next to the bed. He is talking to LANGFORD but we don't see anyone but PUPKIN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Open. (pause) Bite ... Good. He is wrapping LANGFORD's mouth shut but all we see is th he is doing something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you breathe? Both ways?         In and out? WE    PULL    BACK TO SEE LANGFORD    nodding. He is stra the    bed    with tape and encased    like a mummy, only and    nose    showing. PUPKIN has     wrapped him in tap to    toe.     MARSHA emerges from    the kitchen stirrin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to MARSHA)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got until around midnight. Have a good time. (to LANGFORD) So long, Jerry! Wish me luck. PUPKIN leaves.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: The phone rings.        BERT THOMAS' SECRETARY answers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bert Thomas! Who's calling please? (her voice grows tense) Yes, Mr. King.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: THOMAS sits by his phone. There is           a large mach looking like a large tape recorder,          attached to and monitoring the call. GIARDELLO           is at a seco and starts placing a call. PATTEN           stands next t There are two other PLAINCLOTHESMEN          in the room, and CATHY LONG.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly to THOMAS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep him talking. THOMAS nods and picks up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes? ... Yes, Mr, King. We     understand. Everything's been arranged.     Now if you'll just tell me a little    about the nature of your material, so    that we can ...

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: PUPKIN stands in a public phonebooth on a streetcorner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into the phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell you everything you need to know at the studio this evening, Mr. Thomas. I appreciate your co- operation. Goodbye. PUPKIN steps out of the booth and starts walking downtown

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Late afternoon. MARSHA is setting the dining room table for two. She talks as she works.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got so much to tell you I just don't know what to begin with. Are you okay? LANGFORD mumbles incoherently through his gag and tape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. Tell me if you're not. I guess you're wondering why I do stuff like this. I think it's because I'm a Leo, but my shrink says I'm pathologically rebellious and self-destructive. You don't think I'm self-destructive, do you? LANGFORD, mummified, again mumbles and struggles a bit in his bonds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew you wouldn't. That's 'cause you're the only person in the world who really understands me.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: CROCKETT sits behind his desk.    With him are BERT THOMA CATHY LONG and three other EXECUTIVES.

dialogues.speaker: CROCKETT
dialogues.text: Can Randall* sub for Jerry? [*Tony Randall is one of any number of substitute hosts.]

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS
dialogues.text: His agent's calling us back but it looks good. I only told him Jerry's sick.

dialogues.speaker: CROCKETT
dialogues.text: Well, if worse comes to worse, Canter can always carry it. (to CATHY LONG) Let me see your list. CATHY LONG hands CROCKETT a blue piece of paper.   He glances over it quickly.

dialogues.speaker: CROCKETT
dialogues.text: Any one of these a writer?

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS
dialogues.text: (pointing to a name on the list) McCabe. The Vanishing Siberian Tiger.

dialogues.speaker: CROCKETT
dialogues.text: He's out.

dialogues.speaker: CATHY LONG
dialogues.text: What if we don't run this King guy? Who'll fill the time?

dialogues.speaker: CROCKETT
dialogues.text: We'll stretch the other guests. But I think we're going to wind up running him. For one thing, we've got to think about Jerry.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST EXECUTIVE
dialogues.text: And from a news point of view, we've got a responsibility to air this story.

dialogues.speaker: CROCKETT
dialogues.text: Exactly, Lou. (pause) I mean, who would you rather watch -- some tiger expert or a live kidnapper.

dialogues.speaker: A SECOND EXECUTIVE
dialogues.text: But nobody's going to know he's a kidnapper. They'll think we've gone crazy.

dialogues.speaker: CROCKETT
dialogues.text: Then they'll read about it in the papers tomorrow and, believe me, tomorrow night, everyone in America will be watching Jerry talk about his experience. And he can put this King guy on rerun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're going to put him on twice?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if his stuff's unusable?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And remember what Patten said about ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold on. (pause) We can always edit the guy. And, as for a wave of these things, I just don't buy the idea that there are that many people out there crazy enough to spend their lives in prison for a few minutes on television.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: PUPKIN walks purposefully down the street.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: The street is quiet. Suddenly three cars pull up and some dozen PLAINCLOTHESMEN get out. Two wait outside the theater; the ten others disappear inside through the backstage entrance.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: PUPKIN is now walking cross-town, towards the theater.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
