dialogues.text: A line of some 100 PEOPLE has gathered outside the theate A sign at the bottom of the poster showing Langford reads "Tonight's Guest Host: Tony Randall."

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: From the POV of the stage, WE WATCH six PLAINCLOTHESMEN descend into the orchestra and take widely scattered aisl seats. When the last has taken his seat we ...

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: Depending on the season, it is either dusk or late afternoon. The USHERS swing the doors open and the TICKETHOLDERS file in.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: PUPKIN is crossing Broadway, a few blocks from the theate

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: At the center of the stage, a pretty MODEL used solely to test color quality sits in Langford's chair as several MEMBERS of the Tactical Patrol Force admire her considerable cleavage. A number of TECHNICIANS go about their work. CAMERAMEN move to and from their stations.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Four PLAINCLOTHESMEN are gathered behind the stage door. They watch ZSA ZSA GABOR (or some other sexy talk show celebrity) enter and then return to talking among themselves.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: The situation appears normal. Only the regular backstage door GUARD, a big, grey-haired man, stands at the door. Nearby two other young MEN, in colorless suits, stand talking. We WATCH CLARENCE MCCABE, a writer, his plain WIFE and her PARENTS arrive in front of the theater, loca the backstage entrance and present themselves before the GUARD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a bit pompously)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good evening, officer. This is the backstage door I take it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your name please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clarence McCabe, the writer. And this is Mrs. McCabe and her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Leroy Solters of Cleveland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (checking his list)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, sir. I don't see you here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm on the show tonight, officer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you're not here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (getting a bit agitated)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Cathy Long gave me instructions to present myself at a quarter to six. May I see her please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm under strictest orders tonight to admit only authorized personnel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (huffy)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is absurd. (to the others) Wait right here. MCCABE marches past the GUARD and rushes to the backstage door. He opens it. The GUARD trails behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop him!

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: The four PLAINCLOTHESMEN jump MCCABE and start pulling hi downstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey!

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: PUPKIN arrives at the backstage door.      Seeing no one, walks in.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: MCCABE has just been hustled before PATTEN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you the King? MCCABE looks baffled.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: PUPKIN is looking for a familiar face.     He approaches CAMERAMAN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (getting CAMERAMAN's attention)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me. The CAMERAMAN looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm the King.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: PATTEN is sitting behind a desk. MCCABE is standing befor him, still securely held by four PLAINCLOTHESMEN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't talk to me about tigers!

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: PUPKIN approaches the STAGE MANAGER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to STAGE MANAGER)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm the King.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What can I do for you, your highness? CATHY LONG passes by.     She spots PUPKIN, and walks swi over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing here, Mr. Pupkin?!?!

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: The lights are dimmed. Music is playing on the phonograph Two candles burn on the elegantly-set dinner table. MARSH stands in the middle of the room, in front of LANGFORD. She is singing. LANGFORD is still encased in tape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing to the music)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "I'm gonna love you, Like no one's ever loved you, Come rain or come shine, Happy together, unhappy together, And won't it be fine."

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Now PUPKIN stands before PATTEN, held by PLAINCLOTHESMEN who frisk him and hand PATTEN the autograph book. GIARDELLO stands next to PATTEN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the PLAINCLOTHESMEN)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope you brought me the right guy this time. (to PUPKIN) Where's Jerry Langford?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to GIARDELLO)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you on the show?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Mr. King. That's my assistant, Mr. Giardello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to see someone on the show.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you tell us where Mr. Langford is and we'll let you see anyone you want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just get me someone from the show. PATTEN starts browsing through the autograph book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Mr. King. Let's not fool around. (looking up from the book) Should we know about any of these people?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gesturing to the book)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's Orson Bean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see.   (to GIARDELLO)   Check these out. GIARDELLO starts looking through the autograph book.

dialogues.speaker: PATTEN
dialogues.text: Now are you going to talk to us, or not?

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: Sure I'll talk. Just get me someone from the show.

dialogues.speaker: PATTEN
dialogues.text: (to GIARDELLO) Get that Thomas guy in here. GIARDELLO leaves.

dialogues.speaker: PATTEN
dialogues.text: We haven't much time, Mr. King. PUPKIN looks towards the door.

dialogues.speaker: PATTEN
dialogues.text: Let's start with your name.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: Rupert Pupkin.

dialogues.speaker: PATTEN
dialogues.text: That's your real name? PUPKIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir.

dialogues.speaker: PATTEN
dialogues.text: You an American? PUPKIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: PATTEN
dialogues.text: Then why do you people do these things? THOMAS enters.   He scrutinizes PUPKIN.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: Are you on the show? THOMAS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.   I'm Bert Thomas. PUPKIN pulls thin piece of neatly typewritten paper from his inside jacket and hands it to THOMAS.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: Here's the introduction to my act. Please make sure Mr. Randall follows it exactly as I've written it. PATTEN nods to THOMAS who takes the paper and reads it as he leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.   How about helping us, Mr. King?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about make-up?   I need make-up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to PLAINCLOTHESMEN)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put some color in his cheeks.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: MARSHA has finished a half bottle of wine. She is eating a beautifully decorated piece of stuffed capon and talkin through her tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (crying)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was the second lead! I'd never gotten a part in my life and here I get the second lead. And what does Daddy say? SHOT of LANGFORD still bound from tip to toe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not "Marsha, that's wonderful" or "we're proud of you" or anything. Oh no. He starts lecturing me on how I should have tried out for Emily! Now do you understand, Jerry! MARSHA gets hold of herself. She swallows a couple of pills and swills them down with some wine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calmer)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My doctor says I shouldn't get excited. MARSHA picks at another piece of capon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the best I ever made it. You want some? LANGFORD, the mummy, nods. MARSHA picks up the plate across from her, fills it with food, and pulls a chair up next to LANGFORD. She undoes the tape around his mouth and picks a sock out of his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now open.   Marsha's going to feed her Jerry.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Two young GIRLS are working on big cue cards copying from the piece of paper PUPKIN has given THOMAS. TONY RANDALL stands next to THOMAS. The two of them watch. RANDALL is going over the lines.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: PUPKIN has obviously been worked over.   He is sweating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about it, King?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I'm not on that show, Jerry Langford is dead, I promise you. PATTEN nods to his PLAINCLOTHESMEN again who start workin PUPKIN over.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: The beginning of the taping is seconds away. Everyone is in his place. The STAGE MANAGER is counting down from fiv on his fingers. At zero, he points across to RICK ROSS, the orchestra leader, who strikes up the familiar Langfor Show theme song.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Four TECHNICAL ENGINEERS are seated along a large console containing a multitude of small television screens. One screen shows the spotlight falling where Randall will enter. Another shows the logo of the Langford Show. Another shows nothing in particular. Behind the TECHNICIANS, stand CROCKETT and the EXECUTIVES we have seen in the previous scenes. A TECHNICIAN is giving instructions to the CAMERAMAN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold on two. Hold. Hold.    Come on, Keller. Get it framed!

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: The theme song is playing.   BERT CANTER stands off-camer at one side of the stage before a microphone.

dialogues.speaker: CANTER
dialogues.text: Now! Direct from New York! It's the Jerry Langford Show with guest host Tony Randall and his special guests -- Olympic swimmer Mark Spitz, pundit Gore Vidal, the one and only Zsa Zsa Gabor and another of Jerry's taped exclusives, an interview with Prince Ranier of Monaco. As always, Rick Ross and the Orchestra and me, Bert Canter. And now ... say hello to Tony!!!!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An APPLAUSE sign flashes like crazy. The AUDIENCE cheers wildly. In the back, we notice a handful of TACTICAL PATROLMEN scattered about. RANDALL strides on stage briskly, accepting the cheers of the crowd with his arms raised. He nods and then his eyes fix on those hastily written outsized cue cards. He reads them with a mixture of professionalism and wry distance, wanting to disown th words without seeming silly.

dialogues.speaker: RANDALL
dialogues.text: Good evening, ladies and gentlemen. Thank you. Thank you very much. I have some sad news for you. Earlier today, my writing staff was executed in Central Park by the network firing squad so there'll be no sensational Randall monologue this evening. The AUDIENCE cheers derisively.

dialogues.speaker: RANDALL
dialogues.text: No embarrassing displays of emotion, please. (the AUDIENCE laughs) Instead, we're going to do something a little bit different this evening -- a lot different if you ask me. We're going to give you a glimpse into the future. It isn't often that you can call someone a sure thing in the entertainment business. After all, the verdict is always in your hands. But I think tonight, after you've met my first guest, you'll agree with me that he's destined for greatness -- in one way or another. So will you please give your warmest greeting to the newest King of Comedy, Rupert Pupkin!!!! The music plays. The APPLAUSE sign flashes. The AUDIENCE applauds heartily -- and nobody appears to fill the spotlight at the edge of the wings. The spotlight holds for what seems like an eternity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just hold.   Three. Pick up the audience.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Finally after what seems like an eternity, PUPKIN emerges straightening his jacket a bit and trying to crane the kinks out of his neck. He is a bit tense but very high and in full command. As he delivers his monologue, PUPKIN is more confident, comfortable and self-assured than we have ever seen him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good evening, ladies and gentleman. Let me introduce myself. My name is Rupert Pupkin. I was born in Clifton, New Jersey, which was not, at that time, a federal offense. (laughter) Is there anyone here from Clifton? (silence) Good. We can all relax. Now, I'd like to begin by saying that my parents were too poor to afford me a childhood but the fact is nobody is allowed to be really poor in Clifton. Once you fall below eleven thousand you're exiled to Passaic. My parents did, in fact, put down the first two payments on my childhood. Then they tried to return me to the hospital as defective.   But, like everyone else I grew up in large part thanks to my mother. If she was only here today I'd say, "Hey, mom. What are you doing here? You've been dead for nine years?" (laughter) You should have seen my mother. She was wonderful -- blonde, beautiful, intelligent, alcoholic. (laughter) We used to drink milk together after school. Mine was homogenized. Hers was loaded. (laughter) Once she was picked up for speeding. They clocked her doing fifty -- in our garage. (laughter) When they tested her they found that her alcohol was two per cent blood. They took away her license and she died shortly afterwards. We used to joke together Mom and me, until the tears would stream down her face and she'd throw up. (laughter) And who would clean it up? Not Dad. He was too busy down at O'Grady's throwing up on his own. In fact, until I was sixteen, I thought throwing up was a sign of maturity. While the other kids were off in the woods sneaking cigarettes, I was hiding behind the house with my fingers down my throat. (laughter) I never got anywhere until one day, my father caught me. Just as he was giving me a final kick in the stomach, for luck, I managed to heave all over his new shoes. "That's it," I thought. "I've made it. I'm finally a man!" (laughter) As it turned out, that was the only time my father ever paid any real attention to me. He was usually too busy out in the park playing ball with my sister, Rose. And, today thanks to those many hours of practice, my sister Rose has grown into a fine man. (laughter) Me, I wasn't especially interested in athletics. The only exercise I ever got was when the other kids picked on me. They used to beat me up once a week, usually Tuesday. After a while, the school worked it into the curriculum. And, if you knocked me out, you got extra credit. (laughter) Except there was this one kid who was afraid of me. I kept telling him, "Hit me! Hit me! What's the matter with you? Don't you want graduate?" As for me, I was the only kid in the history of the school to graduate in traction. The school nurse tucked my diploma into my sling. But my only real interest, right from the beginning, was show business. Even as a young man, I began at the very top, collecting autographs. (laughter)

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: Dinner is over. MARSHA is sitting next to LANGFORD. As LANGFORD speaks, it is obvious that he is turning on the charm for strategic reasons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was a wonderful dinner, Marsha. I want you to know how much I enjoyed it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can do it again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to show you my gratitude. But it's a little difficult, like this. LANGFORD indicates his bonds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a tone of intimacy)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's say I took all this off.   What would you do to me? Tell me.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: We break in on a great burst of laughter.      PUPKIN is finishing his monologue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lot of you are probably wondering why Jerry couldn't make it this evening. Well, he's tied up -- and I'm the one who tied him. (laughter) You think I'm joking, but that's the only way I could break into show business -- by hijacking Jerry Langford. (laughter) I'm not kidding. Right now, Jerry Langford is strapped to a bedstead somewhere in the middle of this city. (laughter) Go ahead. Laugh. But the fact is ... I'm here. Tomorrow you'll know I wasn't kidding and you'll think I was crazy. But I figured it this way: better to be King for a Night than Schmuck for a Lifetime!!! (laughter) Good night ladies and gentlemen. God bless you. The AUDIENCE applauds heartily. The music plays. And TONY RANDALL salutes PUPKIN with a wave of his hand. PUPKIN goes off stage after soaking up the applause.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: A group of PLAINCLOTHESMEN seize PUPKIN and march him briskly through the backstage corridor towards the backstage door.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: A handful of PEOPLE are waiting, among them the autograph hunters, MAE, CELESTE and SIDNEY. MAE, out of a reflex of thirty years, immediately extends her autograph book towards PUPKIN, then, recognizing him, immediately pulls it back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to PUPKIN)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who did you get? PUPKIN says nothing as he is hustled into a limousine. SIDNEY and CELESTE look on. MAE trails after PUPKIN and the PLAINCLOTHESMEN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to PLAINCLOTHESMAN)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could I have a ride? The PLAINCLOTHESMAN says nothing and starts getting in th limo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've never been in one. The limo pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: PUPKIN stands among a crowd of PLAINCLOTHESMEN who have obviously been working him over. PATTEN sits behind his desk. GIARDELLO is at his side. The clock on the wall reads 10:20.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Pupkin. We'll start all over again. Where is Langford? You know, we're going to find him sooner or later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm trying to tell    you, Inspector. You let me walk out    of here, right? And as soon as I'm    seen my act on the show -- as soon    as I'm sure they've really put it on --    I'll tell you where Jerry is and you'll    get him back safe and sound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine, Pupkin. Then why don't you watch the show here with us? That way we're all happy. (to GIARDELLO) What channel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We get that one in fine.    So what do you say, Pupkin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I'll say it again.    You let me go now. PATTEN motions to the PLAINCLOTHESMEN wearily with his head. They drag PUPKIN off. PATTEN looks up at the clock.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: MARSHA is frantically attempting to unwrap LANGFORD. With each pull of the tape, LANGFORD yelps. There is a small tangle of unwrapped tape collecting around LANGFORD's fee and sticking to MARSHA's clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watch my hair!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, baby. We hear the sound of tape ripping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ow!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: PUPKIN is hustled before PATTEN again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still nothing. PUPKIN glances at the clock.      It is 11:05.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got to get out of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not going anywhere, Pupkin. Now, where is he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm telling you, Inspector,    if I don't see that show where I    want to see it, Jerry Langford is dead. My     people have instructions to execute    him unless they hear from me by    midnight. PATTEN glances apprehensively at GIARDELLO.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just where is it you want to watch this show?

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: LANGFORD is half unwrapped now. The place is covered with yard after yard of tape.   MARSHA is working frantically finish unwrapping LANGFORD who is helping now that his ar are free.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ow!   God damnit! Not so fast!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (working frantically)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We haven't all night, baby. MARSHA rips the tape off LANGFORD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I love you, baby.   I love you so much.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: A limo drives down Broadway, followed by an unmarked car.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: PATTEN and GIARDELLO sit up front, with the DRIVER. PUPKI sits in the back between two PLAINCLOTHESMEN. The limo pulls up in front of the bar-restaurant where RITA works. PATTEN turns around in the front seat to address PUPKIN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here we, are, Pupkin. I don't know what this is all about, but as soon as you've seen yourself, you're going to talk to us or I promise you, you'll never see daylight again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll need a couple of minutes, Inspector.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?!?

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: After it's over, I want a couple of minutes. And I'll need ten dollars. Does anyone of you gentlemen have my wallet?

dialogues.speaker: PATTEN
dialogues.text: Don't push me, Pupkin.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: A condemned man's last request, Inspector.

dialogues.speaker: PATTEN
dialogues.text: Well, I'll tell you right away, the answer is no, Pupkin.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: It's not much of a ransom, Inspector ...

dialogues.speaker: PATTEN
dialogues.text: (losing his temper) Look, I'm drawing the line, that's all! No ten dollars and that's it. (emphatically) No -- ten -- dollars!!!! You understand?!?

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: (in mollifying tones) Sure. Sure, Inspector. No ten dollars ... PATTEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (appeased) Okay.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: ... and no Jerry Langford. There is a pause as PATTEN stifles himself.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: Come on, it's getting late, Inspector.

dialogues.speaker: PATTEN
dialogues.text: (exploding to     one of his MEN) Go ahead. Give him      his goddamned ten dollars! Give him      twenty! I don't care. Just get him      out of here! One of the PLAINCLOTHESMEN in the back opens the door and PUPKIN and the other PLAINCLOTHESMAN get out. The unmarke car has pulled up behind the limo and other PLAINCLOTHESM stand next to it. PUPKIN and the two PLAINCLOTHESMEN star walking the ten yards or so to the bar-restaurant.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: PUPKIN marches in flanked by the PLAINCLOTHESMEN. The clock over the bar reads 11:30. RITA looks up from talkin with a CUSTOMER and sees PUPKIN. She says nothing. She just looks at him. There are five CUSTOMERS at the bar. A working class COUPLE in their late fifties are half-stewe the man telling the woman that her friend, Maud, isn't really her friend because she wants $150 for a used refrigerator. A few seats down, two MEN in their mid- forties, in wind-breakers are locked in an intense but inaudible conversation. And, close to the television set which hangs over the far end of the bar sits a MOUSY MAN with glasses, who looks like an accountant. He is sipping a beer, his eyes fixed on the set where the CBS late movi is just showing its logo. PUPKIN marches up to the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (urgently to RITA)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turn on Langford. Seven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey!   I'm watching this. RITA keeps staring at PUPKIN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just turn it. Come on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was here first, mister. You can't just walk in like this. It isn't fair. RITA glances at the MAN. PUPKIN can't      wait. He vault onto the bar and turns the set to the     Langford Show, as, on screen, he walks from the wings     onto the stage the applause of the studio audience.      Perched atop th standing next to the image of himself,     PUPKIN looks d RITA, a smile of pride and triumph on     his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PUPKIN walking onto television screens in various homes across America -- in a chic New York living room, in a suburban bedroom, in the parlor of an Indiana farmhouse, in a kitchen where a COUPLE is in the middle of a raging domestic quarrel, in an otherwise dark bedroom where a COUPLE is in the throes of lovemaking, in a bar, a statio house, in a television store window display.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: MARSHA has just removed her dress and stands in      her panties as LANGFORD unwraps the last tape from      about ankles. The room is swimming in tape, like an       enorm boa constrictor gone mad. MARSHA moves towards       LANG her arms open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, baby.   Baby. LANGFORD frees his ankles of tape just in time to side-st MARSHA and moves quickly to the dining room table where h grabs the gun. He trains it on her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop! MARSHA moves toward him. He pulls the trigger, releasing a plastic pellet that hits MARSHA in the stomach, stingin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ow! LANGFORD glances down in horror at the gun which he now realizes is a toy and looks up in horror to see MARSHA, bigger than life, bearing down on him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be afraid of Marsha, baby.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: The CUSTOMERS are watching the conclusion of Pupkin's monologue, along with the PLAINCLOTHESMEN and PUPKIN. WE COME IN a split second after a joke. The CUSTOMERS laugh, with the exception of the MOUSY MAN who is waiting, in ba humor, for Pupkin's act to finish. The PLAINCLOTHESMEN laugh reluctantly. PUPKIN, no longer standing on the bar, but back down with the others, watches with fascination. RITA watches grimly, occasionally glancing at PUPKIN. PUPKIN on TV

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I figured it this way: better to be King for a Night than Schmuck for a Lifetime. (audience and CUSTOMERS laugh)   Good night, ladies and gentlemen, and God bless you. The television audience applauds and the CUSTOMERS applau and cheer in good humor except for the MOUSY MAN. The HALF-STEWED MAN leans across his WOMAN to yell at PUPKIN as the two FRIENDS in windbreakers congratulate PUPKIN at the same time. There is a brief moment of carnival excitement.

dialogues.speaker: HALF-STEWED MAN FIRST FRIEND
dialogues.text: Hey, that's pretty good.             (to PUPKIN) Schmuck for a Lifetime!      How do you think up all (to the WOMAN) You know      that stuff? who he's talkin' about? Your brother!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HALF-STEWED WOMAN       It's a trick, that's What about your        all. Larry can do it brother?                as good as him.

dialogues.speaker: HALF-STEWED MAN MOUSY MAN
dialogues.text: What about him?              Is it over now?

dialogues.speaker: HALF-STEWED WOMAN FIRST FRIEND
dialogues.text: He's another one.       He's funnier than Larry. Larry just makes a lot

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HALF-STEWED MAN of faces. (getting a little angry) I told you to shut up about         MOUSY MAN my brother. (to PUPKIN)       Well, if nobody She doesn't know nuthin'.     minds ... PUPKIN takes all this praise and excitement with a shy smile of satisfaction, glancing at RITA from time to time for her reaction. She merely stares at PUPKIN with a sad expression on her face.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: Come on, Rita. Don't spoil the party. (to the CUSTOMERS) Drinks all around on me.

dialogues.speaker: HALF-STEWED MAN
dialogues.text: (in a loud voice, to HALF-

dialogues.speaker: STEWED WOMAN
dialogues.text: What about the hundred and fifty? We never saw a penny outta your brother.

dialogues.speaker: HALF-STEWED WOMAN
dialogues.text: That's because my brother is a family man, not like Phil. The argument between the HALF-STEWED MAN and his WOMAN continues at the end of the bar. The two FRIENDS have resumed their intense conversation.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: (to the two FRIENDS) What'll you have? FIRST FRIEND

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm okay.   Thanks, pal.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND FRIEND
dialogues.text: Me, too. The MOUSY MAN has climbed up on the bar and has turned th TV back to the late movie. He sits enthralled by a scene of violence courtesy of Tony Curtis as the Boston Strangler. PUPKIN looks down the bar at the STEWED COUPLE to offer them drinks, but they are lost in an argument over the relative merits of their brothers. PUPKIN turns to the PLAINCLOTHESMEN.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: I don't suppose you're allowed anything. (to RITA) I guess nobody's in a celebrating mood. How about you? You want something?

dialogues.speaker: FIRST PLAINCLOTHESMAN
dialogues.text: It's getting time, Pupkin.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: In a second.

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: (in a sad, serious voice to PUPKIN) That was true, wasn't it? ... about the kidnapping. PUPKIN nods and shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: Now you can say you knew me.   That's something, anyway.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST PLAINCLOTHESMAN
dialogues.text: Come on, Pupkin.

dialogues.speaker: PUPKIN
dialogues.text: (to RITA, in a quiet, tender voice) I guess I've got go. Take care of yourself, will you. And when you're bored -- you know, when you're brushing your teeth or something, give me a thought, okay?

dialogues.speaker: RITA
dialogues.text: Okay. The PLAINCLOTHESMEN lead PUPKIN out of the bar. The two FRIENDS are still buried in their intense, private conversation. The PLAINCLOTHESMEN and PUPKIN walk past the HALF-STEWED COUPLE.

dialogues.speaker: HALF-STEWED WOMAN
dialogues.text: It's okay to talk about my sister, but we can't say nuthin' about Phil, is that it?

dialogues.speaker: HALF-STEWED MAN
dialogues.text: (to PUPKIN) She's just had one too many. The PLAINCLOTHESMEN lead PUPKIN onto the street.

dialogues.speaker: EXT
dialogues.text: As they walk the few steps to the car, the FIRST PLAINCLOTHESMAN turns to PUPKIN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just don't get    it, Pupkin. You're gonna spend eight    years in the can -- "minimum" -- and    for what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, Pupkin. You threw it all away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (vaguely)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll see. WE CLOSE IN on PUPKIN, smiling.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: The STAGE MANAGER is counting down. At zero, he points to RICK ROSS who launches the orchestra into the Langford Sh theme song. BERT CANTER, standing stage right, speaks int the mike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now! Direct from New York! The Jerry Langford Show, starring Jerry's special guest, out on bail, Rupert Pupkin, the kidnapping King of Comedy!!!! The AUDIENCE applauds mightily and the FINAL CREDITS roll As they roll, the music to the Langford Show continues an WE WATCH a MONTAGE that shows PUPKIN progressively taping LANGFORD to the back of a brass bedstead on stage as the two of them talk and laugh. By the end of the MONTAGE, LANGFORD is once again mummified and PUPKIN, having finished, bows and smiles. WE CLOSE on a FREEZE-FRAME CLOSE UP of PUPKIN in ecstasy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: December 15, 1976 draft Screenplay by Paul D. Zimmerman
